item.title: Macron calls for rebalancing relations with China
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron defended an urgent rebalance in economic relations between the European Union (EU) and China, warning that, without progress, Brussels could be forced to adopt more protectionist measures. In an opinion article published yesterday in the British newspaper Financial Times, Macron highlights that China's trade surplus with the rest of the world has already reached one billion dollars, and that the imbalance with the EU has doubled in the last decade, reaching 300 billion euros. “This situation is not sustainable, neither for Europe nor for China”, he observes. The French head of state recognizes that the current wave of Chinese exports to the European market is partly due to tariffs imposed by the United States and weak domestic consumption in China. However, it states that “responding with tariffs and quotas would be a non-cooperative solution”. Macron rather calls for a coordinated approach that involves three fronts: strengthening European competitiveness, mobilizing savings for domestic investment and encouraging structural reforms in the Chinese economy. “Europe’s first step must be to implement a new economic agenda based on competitiveness, innovation and protection”, he argues. Macron defended Europe's right to adopt a “European preference” to support strategic sectors such as automobiles, energy, health and technology, as long as they comply with international rules. “Protecting against unfair competition is the basis of resilience”, he maintains. As for financing this transformation, the French President proposes channeling part of the approximately 30 billion euros in savings accumulated in the EU – of which 300 billion are invested annually abroad – to European companies. “It’s time for us Europeans to take the risk of investing in our own companies”, he argues. Eyes on China Macron emphasizes, however, that China also has responsibilities. “Beijing needs to correct its internal imbalances”, he states, defending a fiscal policy that is more favorable to consumption and the transition to a service economy. The French President also calls for a rebalance in foreign direct investment (FDI) flows, recalling that the EU invested around 240 billion euros in China, while Chinese investment in Europe was below 65 billion. “Europe must remain open to Chinese investment in sectors where China leads, as long as this contributes to employment, innovation and technological sharing”, he writes. Macron reiterates his call for a framework of economic cooperation between the EU, China and the US, warning that, in the absence of progress, Europe will have to resort to “firmer measures”. "I prefer cooperation. But, if necessary, I will defend the use of protectionist measures", he warns, adding that the French presidency of the G7, next year, will put the rebalancing of global asymmetries at the top of the agenda. “I believe that, if we truly take into account the needs and interests of each person, we can build an international macroeconomic agenda that benefits everyone”, he states.

item.title: Commerce | Mannings closes all stores in the Interior
item.description: On Tuesday, the Mannings Group announced the closure of all physical stores in the Interior as well as the online store and electronic platforms Tmall, JD and Pinduoduo. The closure of physical stores will take place on January 15th. In the case of online stores, the deactivation will take place next week. The closures were explained with the need to adjust the commercial strategy. Despite these closures, customers in the Interior will be able to continue purchasing products through the group's Hong Kong portal. According to company data, Mannings has more than 320 stores in Hong Kong and Macau. Since 2004, the group entered the Interior market, and the number of stores reached 200 units, during the period with the highest demand. Currently, the number of stores is 120 units.

item.title: Ivo M. Ferreira presents new film about terrorist group FP-25
item.description: It’s called “Global Project” and it’s the new film by Ivo M. Ferreira, a Portuguese director who previously lived in the territory. The presentation to the world of cinema is scheduled to take place at the Rotterdam International Film Festival, in January, which takes place in the Netherlands. The feature film is part of the “Big Screen” competition, whose narrative is “anchored in the early 1980s, when Portugal was the scene of attacks and robberies perpetrated by the 25 de Abril Popular Forces (FP-25)”. Ivo M. Ferreira's project, described by the festival as a political thriller “set in the turbulent years after the 'Carnation Revolution'”, features actors such as Jani Zhao, Rodrigo Tomás, José Pimentão, Gonçalo Waddington, Isac Graça, João Catarré, Ivo Canelas, Hugo Bentes, Isabél Zuaa, later giving rise to a series for RTP. According to the producer, the film “Projecto Global” will premiere in Portuguese cinemas on April 23rd of next year. The story focuses on Lisbon in 1980, when Rosa, Jaime and their FP-25 comrades “slide into an armed spiral where morale unravels, loyalty falters and each step opens a deeper abyss”. “Apart from themselves and with the dreams of the past in ruins, they no longer recognize the country they are crossing, and even less the people they have become”, describes the synopsis. Ivo M. Ferreira is also linked to the local cinema scene, having directed the feature film “Hotel Império” in Macau in 2016, starring Margarida Vila-Nova. His film, “Letters from War”, was also shown in Macau. Salvador's debut Another Portuguese film premiering at the Rotterdam film festival is “A Providência e a Guitarra”, by João Nicolau, having its world premiere here, outside of competition. This is a project that was born from a short story by writer Robert Louis Stevenson, and is performed by Pedro Inês, Clara Riedenstein, Isac Graça, Jenna Thiam, Américo Silva and musician Salvador Sobral. Shot in the summer of 2024, the film is presented as “a dive into the hardships and delights of artistic life and an exploration of its consequences” on marital and social relationships, and marks Salvador Sobral's debut in cinema. “A Providência e a Guitarra” is produced by O Som e a Fúria. In Rotterdam, the program for short and medium-length films will also include the short films “O”, by actress and director Francisca Alarcão, an experimental fiction about an aversion to navels, and “Computer”, by visual artist Alice dos Reis, which “intertwines history and fiction in a fun narrative about the female perspective and self-determination”, describes the festival. The 55th Rotterdam Film Festival will take place from January 29th to February 8th in the Netherlands.

item.title: Housing | Fewer transactions and cheaper homes
item.description: The housing market continues to decline consistently. In annual terms, November saw a 20.4 percent reduction in the number of transactions and a 10.9 percent reduction in the average price per square meter In November, the number of housing transactions showed an annual reduction of 20.4 percent, according to the most recent data published by the Directorate of Financial Services (DSF). Last month, 238 transactions were registered, compared to 299 transactions in November 2024, a reduction of 61 transactions. The most active market in November this year was the Macau Peninsula with 173 transactions, 35 fewer than last year, which represented a drop of 16.8 percent. In Taipa, 44 housing sales were registered, 24 fewer than last year, when 68 were registered. Finally, in Coloane, 21 transactions were registered, a reduction of two sales compared to the same period last year. In terms of housing prices, the month of November was marked by a reduction in the square meter, compared to the same month in 2024, from 74,364 patacas to 69,311 patacas. This represented an annual difference of 5,053 patacas or 6.8 percent. The price reduction was common to all three markets. In Coloane, the average price per square meter fell from 93,970 patacas to 83,707 patacas, a difference of 10.9 percent. In the Peninsula and Taipa prices also showed a negative trend. In Macau, the square meter depreciated in the space of one year from 70,526 patacas to 66,303 patacas, a difference of 6.0 percent. In Taipa, the reduction was from 78,144 patacas to 71,155 patacas, an annual devaluation of 8.9 percent. Double negative The monthly comparison also shows a market shrinking in terms of the number of transactions and prices charged. Between October and November this year, the average price per square meter decreased by 4.9 percent, from 72,873 patacas per square meter to 69,311 patacas per square meter. The price reduction was due to the Peninsula market, with a decrease from 72,629 patacas to 66,303 patacas, corresponding to 8.7 percent, and Coloane, with a reduction in prices from 87,535 patacas to 83,707 patacas, corresponding to 4.4 percent. In Taipa, the square meter appreciated by 11.5 percent in the space of one month from 63,802 patacas to 71,155 patacas, contrary to the general trend.

item.title: SJM | Green light for the acquisition of L’Arc casino
item.description: The Government yesterday approved the deal that will “save” the only satellite casino in the territory, giving the green light to the acquisition of Royal Arc by SJM Resorts. The approval, which comes two days after the group's shareholders voted in favor, required opinions from several public services It's official. The L’Arc casino is part of the portfolio of properties operated by the gaming concessionaire SJM Resorts. The Government gave the green light to the deal yesterday through an order from the Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam Vai Man, published in the Official Bulletin. The approval allows gaming to operate, beyond December 31, 2025, at the only satellite casino in the territory to survive the changes that regulate the casino industry. Therefore, the order from the Secretary for Transport and Public Works indicates that “the transfer of the concession was authorized, in accordance with what was proposed in the opinion of the Land Commission”, after the request to transfer the fraction where the casino and hotel is located was presented on November 11th. In the request, SJM claimed that the “transmission aims to maintain the continuous exploration and operation of the casino existing in that autonomous fraction, which operates as a satellite casino, transforming it into a casino belonging to the gaming concessionaire”. In addition to the positive opinion of the Land Commission, after a meeting on December 4th, the transfer received approval from several public services. “After gathering the opinions of the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Directorate and the Tourism Services Directorate, the request was assessed by the Land and Urban Construction Services Directorate, which ruled in favor as there were no outstanding prizes, fees, rents, fees or taxes relating to the concession and there was no evidence that the transfer was requested for speculative purposes”, is stated in the order from Raymond Tam Vai Man. Step by step The building where the casino is located has “62 floors, including two refuge floors, two mezzanine floors and three basement floors, intended for housing, commerce, a 5-star hotel, residential parking and hotel parking”. It is recalled that SJM Holdings held an extraordinary general meeting on Monday where shareholders voted overwhelmingly in favor of the acquisition of the former satellite casino L’Arc, according to a note sent by the group to the Hong Kong stock exchange. The acquisition, approved by 99.93 percent, will cost HK$1.75 billion. Nine of Macau's 11 “satellite casinos” have already closed. The last to close its doors, on December 9th, was Fortuna, with more than 550 employees. The tenth, Landmark, which has 1,169 workers, will close on December 30th. SJM highlighted that all employees of the 'satellite casinos' with resident status in Macau and directly hired by the company have guaranteed employment in other casinos in the group. As for other local workers, “they are invited to apply for related vacancies” within the group, “with priority for hiring” and with conditions equal to those they had.

item.title: FAOM | New leadership led by Lam Lon Wai wants more patriotism
item.description: Promoting patriotism is the top priority of the new leadership of the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau, which will be led by deputy Lam Lon Wai Patriotism is the main priority of the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau (FAOM) for the coming years. The guarantee was left by Lam Lon Wai, who on Tuesday was elected as the new president of the board, after the first ordinary meeting of the FAOM board. Speaking to the newspaper Ou Mun, Lam Lon Wai stated that he will continue to promote the association's “glorious tradition of love for the country and Macau”, uniting workers in supporting the governance of the Macao SAR, in accordance with the laws in force. The president of the association also pointed out that he will focus on improving FAOM's services, in order to contribute to the “practice of the ‘One Country, Two Systems’ principle”, while increasing the “attraction, cohesion and service capacity” that the association provides. In relation to the remaining members of the association, at a lower hierarchical level compared to Lam Lon Wai, Kong Ioi Fai was elected president of the association's administration. Although he is not a deputy, Kong was the representative of the FAOM list, the Union for Development, in the last legislative elections held on September 14th. Regarding the goals for this mandate, Kong Ioi Fai indicated that the objectives include defending labor rights, increasing participation in governance, bridging the gap between the population and the Government, and also promoting a more harmonious society. The association also promises to work to implement new unions, in light of the new law. Patriotism in companies Kong Ioi Fai also revealed that the association will focus on promoting patriotism in the labor sector, hoping to create a strong patriotic culture in companies. This commitment involves developing manuals and content for workers on patriotism. The official also revealed that the association will continue to organize professional skills competitions and award activities, to highlight employees considered to be excellent in different areas. At the same time, the new management will organize more classes on artificial intelligence and cross-border e-commerce, to train the qualified staff needed for Macau's economic diversification. Kong Ioi Fai also highlighted that FAOM will explore Zone A of the New Urban Landfills and provide more social support. In relation to the remaining positions of the new FAOM board, the president of the previous board, Ho Sut Heng, was elected as president of the Supervisory Board. Some of the most popular members of recent years are retained in the new leadership, such as current deputies Ella Lei, Leong Sun Iok, Leong Pou U and former deputies Lei Chan U and Lee Chong Cheng. The new management will take office on January 20th.

item.title: Government | Secretaries committed to complying with Xi’s instructions
item.description: In the aftermath of the assessment of a year of governance presented by Sam Hou Fai in Beijing, the holders of the main public positions promised their commitment to articulating with the 15th five-year plan. Furthermore, they committed to guiding the course of Macau's development through the “important instructions” given by Xi Jinping The entire government team, and other holders of the main positions such as the Commissioner against Corruption, or the MSAR Prosecutor, issued statements yesterday demonstrating their commitment to complying with the guidelines given by President Xi Jinping during the presentation of the balance sheet of the first year of governance of the Executive led by Sam Hou Fai in Beijing. Even before arriving in Macau yesterday afternoon, the Chief Executive “expressed his sincere gratitude to the President for the full recognition of the work of the MSAR government, as well as for the valuable guidance and important instructions”. Sam Hou Fai stressed that the Government will “seriously” study and understand the guidelines given by Xi Jinping, “as well as firmly implement them” in next year’s Lines of Government Action. It is recalled that Xi Jinping indicated that Sam Hou Fai led the new Government of the Macao SAR in resolute advancement and pragmatic action, in the firm defense of the country's sovereignty, security and development interests, “fully recognizing the work carried out by the Chief Executive and the Government of the Macao SAR”. The Chinese President stressed that governance must be linked to the 15th Five-Year Plan, “insisting and improving the predominance of Executive power, solidly promoting the development of adequate diversification of the economy, constantly increasing the efficiency of governance and better integrating the national development situation and serving it”. Widespread enthusiasm The reactions of all secretaries followed in a succession of statements. The Secretary for Administration and Justice, Wong Sio Chak, “stated that the important instructions given by President Xi Jinping guided Macau's development path”, and that all his staff are “very enthusiastic” and committed to implementing the guidelines. Like all secretaries, Wong Sio Chak guaranteed that “the Administration and Justice area will act proactively in conjunction with the country's 15th Five-Year Plan”, and continue to deepen the reform of public administration, promote electronic governance and improve the functioning of public services. The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture stated that Xi Jinping's “important guidelines” reinforced confidence and were a “great stimulus for the team” under her supervision. Lam added that the President's instructions “are far-sighted, presenting a strong political, ideological, strategic and guiding dimension”, which will be taken as a “guide for action”. In the same vein, the Secretary for Transport and Public Works stated that the 15th National Five-Year Plan systematically outlines a grand project for national development over the next five years”. Raymond Tam Vai Man highlighted the provisions on optimizing the regional economic layout and the Greater Bay Area, which “provide fundamental guidance for work in the area of Transport and Public Works”. transport infrastructures and expanded urban space through landfills and urban renewal. Guardians of the country The Secretary for Economy and Finance, Anton Tai Kin Ip, also stated that he will implement President Xi Jinping's important guidelines. Furthermore, he guaranteed that “the functions of ‘a center, a platform, a base’ will be consolidated, taking advantage of Macau’s unique advantage as a ‘precision interlocutor’ between China and Portuguese-speaking countries to promote cooperation with these countries”. The secretary added that his authority is committed to expanding international exchanges, “well narrating the Macau chapter of the Stories of China”. In turn, the Secretary for Security committed to “firmly safeguarding the sovereignty, security and development interests of the State, defining the direction under the leadership of the 15th Five-Year Plan, preparing for adversities in prosperous times”. The intensification of prevention and reduction of the effects of natural disasters was also highlighted by Chan Tsz King, who committed to acting “by contributing to the construction of a strong country and to the great cause of national rejuvenation with Chinese-style modernization”. Another priority advanced by Chan Tsz King was the facilitation of border crossings, with particular focus on the connection between Macau and Hengqin. The director-general of the Customs Services (SA), Adriano Marques Ho, assured that, “as guardians of national security”, he will “unswervingly implement the requirements of the “general perspective of national security”, combating “severely” all activities that threaten national security. The official added that the SA is “burdened with the heavy responsibility of safeguarding the economic order of the Macao SAR.” The Commissioner against Corruption, Ao Ieong Seong, chose to highlight that the 15th Five-Year Plan requires lucidity and firmness in the fight against corruption and abuses of power. Upon arrival During the presentation to Xi Jinping of the balance of his governance, Sam Hou Fai realized the great importance and concern that the Chinese President and the Central Government attach to the development of Macau, said the Chief Executive upon arrival in the Macao SAR, still at the airport. The local official reiterated his “sincere thanks” for Beijing’s support and assured that he will unite and lead all sectors of society to study, implement and fully execute Xi Jinping’s “important” speeches and instructions, according to the Chinese channel Radio Macau. Sam Hou Fai also stated that the guidelines indicated by the Chinese President will guide the planning of the Executive's key tasks for next year and beyond. According to the Chief Executive, the Chinese leader called for improvements in the legal system and law enforcement mechanisms to safeguard national security.

item.title: UCM | White Paper suggests methods to accelerate economic diversification
item.description: The “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, produced at the City University of Macau, refers to inequalities in the relationship between countries and concludes that “economic diversification has advanced at a slow pace”. Bárbara Morais, main writer of the document, explains the main conclusions of the analysis On December 3rd, a White Paper was launched that provides a look and analysis of the way in which cooperation in scientific and technological areas between China, Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries has been taking place, outlining some criticisms, not only on this topic, but also on the economic direction that the Macao SAR is taking. The document, entitled “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, was produced by the City University of Macau (UCM) and had Bárbara Morais, a doctoral student at the institution, as main writer. In an interview with HM, she describes that, in Macau, “economic diversification has advanced at a slower pace than desired, keeping the economy structurally dependent on gambling and tourism”. "The central message of the White Paper is clear: Macau needs to accelerate the transition to functions with greater added value. However, the current context offers a renewed window of opportunity. With the support of the Greater Bay Area and, very specifically, the Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin, Macau now has new structural opportunities to recover lost momentum and reposition itself, not just as a cultural bridge, but as a true platform for innovation", he said. Still on the territory, but in relation to Forum Macau, the “success in institutionalizing political dialogue” is mentioned, but the White Paper “points the finger at the insufficiency of execution mechanisms”. “To streamline the role of the Forum and transform it into a tool for tangible results, the White Paper advocates a paradigm shift: it is necessary to move from declarations of intent to technicality”, describes Bárbara Morais. The doctoral student suggests “the creation of specialized technical working groups, especially in the technological sphere, and the rigorous definition of performance indicators, such as the number of registered patents, startups created or joint research projects”. “At the same time, it is suggested to establish a common agenda focused on areas of the future, such as green energy, health, the maritime economy and artificial intelligence, subject to a periodic assessment of progress”, he also said. The place of arbitration Taking these meager developments into account, the White Paper suggests that Macau assert itself “as a center for technological arbitration and intellectual property governance”. HM questioned Bárbara Morais about what should be done in effective terms, taking into account the existence, for several years, of an arbitration center, and the fact that it has been a topic on the territory's political agenda for a long time. The doctoral student highlights that “in order for these ideas, debated for years, to stop being rhetoric and become reality, the Macao SAR needs to create a legal framework specialized in technological disputes aligned with the most demanding international standards”. "It is essential to attract international experts and arbitrators through competitive incentives and establish an arbitration center that enjoys recognition both in Portuguese-speaking countries and in the Greater Bay Area. The objective is to develop mediation, certification and management services for intellectual property assets, positioning Macau as a 'safe haven', neutral and efficient, for the resolution of international technological disputes", he added. Unequal cooperation In global terms, and with regard to cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries (PLP), the White Paper refers to “top planning” by Beijing for cooperation in universities and scientific research. However, planning “does not translate, linearly, into equally effective execution mechanisms on the ground, nor does it guarantee homogeneous results among the nine Portuguese-speaking countries”. Planning implies “clear guidelines, defined priorities and diplomatic instruments mobilized to guide this cooperation”, with policies such as “Made in China 2025” or the “Digital Silk Road”, which “integrate technological cooperation with the PLP into the very core of Chinese foreign policy and national innovation”, highlights the author. However, there are “inequalities, which are perhaps the most striking feature of this relationship”, as Bárbara Morais explains. “The current scenario reveals a profound asymmetry, characterized by a ‘bicephaly’ in cooperation. (…) The main scientific capabilities, the robust technological infrastructure and the volume of effective cooperation are overwhelmingly concentrated in Portugal and Brazil”. On the contrary, “Portuguese-speaking African countries (PALOP) and Timor-Leste have a significantly lower participation”. According to Bárbara Morais, the “disparity does not arise from a lack of political will, but rather from structural funding limitations, a shortage of qualified human resources and the fragility of local research institutions”. Thus, there is “two-speed cooperation, very asymmetrical within the Portuguese-speaking community itself”. The White Paper highlights the “historic crossroads” in relation to cooperation between China and the PLP, which means “the urgent need to move from potential to implementation” in this matter. "There are ambitious visions and strategic plans, but practical results remain below what is possible. To resolve this crossroads, the proposed path involves strengthening execution mechanisms, investing massively in talent and technical-scientific education, creating ecosystems of genuine collaborative innovation between China, Macau and the PLP, and, above all, having the courage to measure results and reformulate strategies based on empirical evidence, abandoning the discourse of circumstance in favor of economic and scientific pragmatism." Gaps in Africa Another of the conclusions of the White Paper is the “tenuity” of academic links with the African continent, which Bárbara Morais describes as a “fragile scenario”. “There is a triad of factors: the scarcity of installed scientific capacity, the chronic lack of funding and consistent mobility programs”, without forgetting “the absence of stable joint research structures”. “To bridge this gap and create a lasting critical mass, the White Paper is not limited to diagnosis, suggesting concrete measures such as the robust reinforcement of research grants, the creation of joint doctoral programs, the implementation of collaborative laboratories and the design of academic mobility mechanisms specifically oriented to the African reality”, he adds. The document also talks about the negative impact of “geopolitical asymmetries”, such as the “technological restrictions of the European Union and NATO on Portugal”. According to Bárbara Morais, “real and restrictive impacts” are at stake. "These limitations condition the participation of Portugal and, by extension, of other Portuguese-speaking actors that cooperate in a network with Lisbon, in high-technology projects that involve China. The impact is particularly sensitive in critical areas such as 5G telecommunications, defense, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity, creating barriers that require complex diplomatic navigation." New strategies The White Paper was developed at the UCM Research Institute on Portuguese-Speaking Countries, and written by Bárbara Morais with the participation of academic João Simões. The project is based on a review of academic literature on the topic and also on the results of the “Technological Cooperation Launch Seminar”, held on July 22, 2025 at UCM. The work analyzes areas such as “strategic evolution”, “institutional mechanisms”, “technological milestones” and “structural challenges”, aiming to “provide evidence-based strategies to transform the potential of the China-PLP partnership into a concrete reality, creating a new model of technological cooperation for the Global South”, says a statement from UCM.

Shot in the summer of 2024, the film is presented as “a dive into the hardships and delights of artistic life and an exploration of its consequences” on marital and social relationships, and marks Salvador Sobral's debut in cinema. “A Providência e a Guitarra” is produced by O Som e a Fúria. In Rotterdam, the program for short and medium-length films will also include the short films “O”, by actress and director Francisca Alarcão, an experimental fiction about an aversion to navels, and “Computer”, by visual artist Alice dos Reis, which “intertwines history and fiction in a fun narrative about the female perspective and self-determination”, describes the festival. The 55th Rotterdam Film Festival will take place from January 29th to February 8th in the Netherlands.

item.title: Music | Mariza in Macau for New Year's concert
item.description: As part of the 2025-2026 concert season, the concert between Portuguese fado singer Mariza and the Macau Orchestra is scheduled for the last day of the year, in the large auditorium of the Macau Cultural Center. Here is a unique opportunity to see, or revisit, one of the great names of Fado, in a mix with classical music Fado singer Mariza will perform in Macau in a concert that marks the arrival of a new year. “Mariza, the Queen of Fado and the Macau Orchestra (OM)” is the name given to this concert that takes place in the large auditorium of the Macau Cultural Center (CCM) on December 31st, starting at 8pm. According to a note from the Cultural Institute (IC), Mariza will perform, “with her deeply emotional voice, a selection of iconic fados, providing the public with a musical experience that transcends genres and spatial and temporal boundaries”. The fado singer is described “as one of the biggest international Fado stars, being recognized for her own musical style, which incorporates elements of soul, jazz and gospel”. "With her powerful voice, she has moved audiences on the most prestigious stages in the world. In this concert, Mariza will present with OM a repertoire that combines traditional and contemporary fado, enriched by the rhythms of Mornas from Cape Verde, 'rhythm and blues' and sounds from Brazil, Spain and Mozambique", being "a celebration of fado with a personal and diverse style". Mariza made her world debut in 1999, having since released several Fado albums, with sales exceeding one million copies worldwide, winning over legions of admirers. She was named Best European World Music Artist three times by BBC Radio 3. The albums “Terra” and “Mundo” earned her nominations for the Latin Grammy Awards, consolidating her status as a global star and her musical influence. The concert will last approximately 1h30 without intermission, and tickets are already on sale, with prices ranging between 180 and 400 patacas. New sounds on the way After releasing “Mariza Canta Amália” in 2020, the artist has dedicated herself to the stage. But last year he released a new single, “Casa”, in 2024, a song from the new album, “Amor”. The fado singer also released the single “Desamor”, which is also part of this album, and in which Mariza collaborates with another musician very different from herself – GSON, from the band Wet Bed Gang, a Portuguese rap group. Quoted by Blitz magazine, during the presentation of “Desamor”, Mariza said that “it would be unlikely that two musicians from completely different backgrounds would meet, but our backgrounds are on the other side of history”. GSON said that “the fact that we are from different poles is what makes the difference in what is being done here”. About the new album, Mariza told the same publication that she was inspired by the various forms of love that exist. “Love of longing, mother's love, family love... love, for me, is not just physical, it goes far beyond that.” Meanwhile, OM announced another musical initiative, planned to take place next year. This is the “Esperança do Futuro” concert, scheduled for May 16th, and whose recruitment program for young local musicians ended on December 12th.

item.title: Japan | Chinese tourism in Japan slows down in November
item.description: The arrival of Chinese tourists to Japan slowed down in November, amid diplomatic tension between Tokyo and Beijing, despite the archipelago having registered a record number of foreign visitors, according to official data released yesterday. The total number of international tourist arrivals in November was 3,518,000, an increase of 10.4 percent compared to the same month in 2024, indicated the Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO). Among the visitors, 562 thousand came from mainland China – a year-on-year increase of 3 percent, but well below previous months. In October, Japan had received 715 thousand Chinese tourists and, in September, 775 thousand – growth of close to 20 percent year-on-year. “In addition to the demand for travel to Japan slowing down at this time of year, the Chinese Government warned the population to avoid traveling to the country”, said JNTO, highlighting that the year-on-year increase was also due to the greater supply of seats on flights. The slowdown coincided with the recommendation issued by Chinese authorities following statements by Japanese Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, about Taiwan, which reignited diplomatic tensions between the two countries. Even so, between January and November, China remained the main source of tourists to Japan, with 8.7 million visitors, followed by South Korea (8.4 million). In the first eleven months of 2025, Japan received 39,065,600 international visitors – 17 percent more than in the same period of the previous year –, already surpassing the record of 36.87 million registered in 2024 and approaching the target of 40 million by the end of this year. The continued growth of tourism has fueled a national debate about the impacts of mass tourism, with some conservative parties demanding new restrictions on the entry of foreigners and stricter rules to preserve coexistence in local communities.

item.title: Macau Initiative | Manifesto defends investment in technology
item.description: The International Forum for Civilizational Exchange ended yesterday with the release of the 'Macau Initiative' of a manifesto that calls on young people to take advantage of technology in the service of dialogue and cooperation between civilizations. At the closing ceremony, the president of the Macau Cultural Institute, which organized the forum, read the document, which “encourages young people to take advantage of new technologies, such as digitalization and smart applications”. Leong Wai Man stated that it is necessary to train new generations “so that they become heirs and innovators of mutual learning between civilizations” and build a world that is “inclusive, cooperative and forward-looking”. The manifesto also defends the need to not only protect the shared heritage of humanity, but also to reinforce “the innovative use of the various forms of tangible and intangible cultural heritage”. The document calls for “deep exploration of the contemporary value of the historical cultures of all countries”, using “creative transformation” to apply “traditional wisdom” in the modern world. Macau is the ideal place for this initiative, says the manifesto, due to the “valuable experience of harmonious coexistence of civilizations reflected in the historic center” of the region. The forum also marked 20 years since the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) classified the historic center of Macau as a World Heritage Site in 2005.

item.title: Carlos Morais José
item.description: Our approach to reality, no matter how disciplined and honest the approach to thought, is always ridden by error, especially when there is no alternative to the use of imagination. Geniuses, the ancient Greeks knew about the Earth's sphericity and that's why they attributed a maximum circle to the planet, which they named Ison. Today we call it Ecuador. However, these Hellene geographers considered these regions to be unreachable and uninhabitable. Torrid Zone: there, unbearable heat would boil the oceans, preventing the passage to temperate zones, postulated further south of this line that marked the maximum circle of the sphere. A simple islet, named “das Rolas”, a mere hundred meters from the island of São Tomé, in the Gulf of Guinea, is crossed by this equatorial line. This location of the former Portuguese colony provides it with a type of climate that is only found with such intensity close to the equator: the temperature varies little and, contrary to what the Greeks thought, it does not reach excessive values. Its range is between 20 and 29 degrees Celsius, but the “normal” temperature remains between 23 and 25 degrees. Night, day and throughout the year. In the permanently cloudy sky, the Sun and Moon are rarely seen. And when this happens, they never fail to appear wrapped in veils of clouds, which gives them an unreal character, invoking ancient magic, witnessing moving skies. When, towards the end of the afternoon, the rain extends its reign for more than two or three hours, often presented to plants and animals by a thunderstorm, the light dies and a very dark night reigns over the land and sea. The stars fall beyond the clouds that cover everything. On a night like this, there is no moonlight to illuminate or pierce the clouds. A deep pitch falls on the earth, a darkness that is impenetrable to our eyes. And it was like that, at three in the morning, that I woke up. My eyes opened to an abysmal darkness. Nothing, absolutely nothing could be seen. He knew he had the window open, but not a ray of light deigned to enter the room. I reached out, but the lamp didn't work. The electricity was out again. I waited for some time, hoping to get used to the blackness and discover some shapes in it. In vain. He was immersed in a well of black, warm water, he could feel the humidity on his skin, which had just woken up sweaty from a nightmare. I decided to get up and leave the house, looking for some light. The rain had stopped. Outside, the forest celebrated, hummed, reverberated with sounds. There would be millions of insects, amphibians, vertebrates, all of them nocturnal animals, also immersed in the dark, where they found food, sex and salvation. Life didn't need light. It was heard, deafening. At the edge of that spontaneous excess of trees and plants, nothing could be seen either. Dark, impenetrable dark. Only the sound prevailed, louder and louder, and suggested movements among the trees. That mixture of buzzing, squealing, buzzing, ringing, rales, loudly surrounded my ears, building a helmet that blocked all other senses, including the one that affects me in space. I was dizzy. And in that half-daziness, I groped my way back to the house, to my bed. There was nothing he could do. Forget the coffee, eliminate the possibility of reading or consulting a computer. Lying in the dark as if waking up in a coffin. Our mind cannot handle fear for long. Mostly irrational. As was the case. I can't really talk about fear, fear, but about discomfort, derived from the fragile situation that I attributed to myself. Everything could happen in that dark, and I wouldn't see him. If for some reason you had to leave the room, where would you go, if everything was plunged into darkness? But nothing was happening in the darkness of my room, nor would anything happen that would force me to grope through the pitch black, looking for a light. On the contrary, in that bed I was protected by the dark and if I saw nothing nothing would see me either. This thought provided some comfort. All things considered, that abysmal pitch was strangely comfortable for me. I made it a protective cloak and not a space of threats. And so I remained. The ancient Chinese say that everyone has an excellent place to stay. A place where you can develop and enjoy who you really are. Maybe this dark package is mine. Perhaps in it I can be for myself what I really am, setting aside what surrounds me, instructs and distracts me. I am undoubtedly alone. Without the possibility of communicating with another person or even acting in my surroundings. I'm left. With me. Alone. Isolated. Here I am not the anthropologist, nor the editor, none of my social titles perform any functions. I am not the husband, the friend or the lover. From the outside I only have the language that inhabits me and my brain rebels in search of meaning. And even this takes second place in daydreams whose material seems to emerge from another place, from knowledge not conditioned to a language — an impression of the world and not its explanation. I am a consciousness separated from things, which in the dark finds its most intimate relationship with the universe, of almost dissolution, a chamazita, a fiery being, whose interior insists on shining in the dark night. The universe and me. I'm unique. Nothing can divide me without destroying me. I know I am an individual, because I feel it deeply, with an almost painful acuity, even though neurologists tell me about the Self as an evolutionary fiction, structuralists see me as a product of Culture, psychoanalysts as a Family and Marxists as History. item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Li Jie, the poet and painter of the 12th century, imagined a peaceful place in the midst of nature where, finally available, he could receive as much as he could perceive and feel. In a horizontal scroll he made in 1170, he represented this site of the Fisherman's Pavilion on Mount Xisai, where he would one day actually retreat fourteen years later. This persistent desire for communion with the slow natural world, shared by so many busy scholars, had already led some, many years before, to recreate in cities miniature similes of these places not yet altered by human hands, called penjing, “landscapes in a vase”, where they could observe the mysterious mutation. For others, poets and painters, nothing replaced the experience of being there, in the enclosed space of a garden. In the eighteenth century, to paint a portrait of a personality, to show their character, painters often depicted them in a garden, preferably in their garden. A court painter named Yan Hongzi, active circa 1751–after 1760, in his 1759 portrait of Jingweng (1710–after 1759), a court official, showed him in his garden with the ambiguous name Yiyuan, the "Natural, Proper, Satisfactory Garden" (horizontal scroll, ink on paper, 34.5 x 348 cm, in the Museum Angewandte kunst Frankfurt). And he wrote a comment on it, playing on the ambiguity of the yi sinogram: «I met old Mr. Jingweng of Beihai at the official district office of his boss, Mr. Hu. Our beds were facing each other and we lived together, happily and cheerfully, for a whole month. When the master asked me to make him a painting titled “Yiyuan”, I looked around and said with a laugh: “Isn’t there just in this expression, appropriate satisfaction?” He said: “Appropriate satisfaction like this is already complete satisfaction.” Oh! Although there is nothing for this gentleman that is not adequate satisfaction, he finds natural satisfaction in this garden. That’s why I made this painting of him.” Yan Hongzi would pay another visit to a mythical garden, which in the past gave so much satisfaction to seven wise men. Since the third century, the story has been told of seven literati who took refuge in a bamboo forest, close to the home of one of them, Ji Kang (c.223-262) in Shanyang (present-day Henan). Removed from the hypocrisy and dangers of the world of politics, the seven poets and philosophers, Zhulin qixian, dedicated themselves to the arts. In the horizontal scroll (ink on paper, 33.3 x 67.6 cm, at the Princeton University Art Museum) by Yan Hongzi, they are shown in their Daoist-inspired occupations, writing on the smooth faces of rocks, painting, reciting poetry into the air. At the end of the scroll, walking in the opposite direction, looking back, are two young people with scrolls to write or paint, a pot of wine: the wise men would remain satisfied.

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description:
By Ana Cristina Alves, Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center1 The Taoist philosophy of the beginnings, that of Laozi and the Book of Way and Virtue (《道德经/經》), will choose the water of the ocean and the sea as the privileged image of the Tao (道 Dào), that which cannot be said, without form, on which the universe itself and the ten thousand beings (万物 wânwù) that inhabit it depend, as well as the first principles of existence, the void (無/无 wú), the masculine yang (陽/阳 yáng) and the feminine yin (阴/隂yīn). This choice of an indigenous Chinese philosophy finds its echo in popular language and philosophy, for example in expressions such as “enormous capacity” (海量Hǎiliàng), which can have both an affective and social interpretation of portentous generosity or magnanimity, as well as a physical and concrete one, applying to someone who can ingest large quantities of alcohol. The sea is also linked to the word good and constant, for example in the “oath of eternal love as energetic as the sea and firm as the mountain”, where mountain lends added firmness to the promise (海誓山盟 or 山盟海誓Hǎishì-Shānméng or Shānméng-Hǎishì). The ocean, the sea, but also the great rivers are made up of generous water, both in popular and erudite Taoist philosophy. Here water is the figurative model of the Tao, as read in the Book of Way and Virtue and in the best sinology, which is why we recommend additional reading of Alan Watts Tao: The Watercourse Way. It is worth paying special attention to the chapters in which water appears as the closest representation of the Tao in the Book of Way and Virtue, namely: chapters 8, 14, 34, 66 and 78. In chapter 8 we are informed that the Tao is the supreme good “like water” (上善如水) (Abreu, 2014, 43), but it is not water itself. Therefore, it will be due to the similarity of functions that both are compared. Now water is generous, granting life to all beings, without establishing any distinction between them, its gift reaches even those that no one likes and I am thinking, for example, of parasites. It remains close to the earth to fertilize it, it is deep, simple, true, fair and correct and very timely, when it washes and cleans at the right time. This is also the case with the Tao. In the first verses of chapter XIV, regarding the Tao, an aquatic image appears again:
You look and you don't see, It's called Indistinct. You listen and you don't hear, It's called Silent. Touch and don't get caught, It's called Subtle. This trio is not decipherable For it merges into a unity 2 (Ribeiro, 2004, 32-33) And a little later we are told that he is nameless and uninterrupted (繩繩不可名) (Ibidem) The Tao is like an ocean, an uninterrupted and inexhaustible unity in which someone easily imagines themselves swimming in water that is neither too bright nor too dark, as would happen to Michael Saso in his 14th meditation on the Tao, in A Taoist Cookbook. with Meditations from the Laozi DaodeJing, which he called “Nadar no Tao” (Saso, 1994,47), a meditation that he accompanied by a recipe for spinach, soy paste and sesame, since the wise man is the one who “empties the mind and fills the belly” (虛其心實其復) (Ribeiro, 2004, 10-11), here one feels how the author is immersed in the great Tao, following with the current. Water can also be represented in a large river, as in chapter 34: The great Tao floods like a river, To the left, to the right, Ten thousand beings depend on him. （大道泛兮/其可左右/万物恃之而生） (Abreu, 2013, 94-95) In the same chapter we are told that the Tao not only gives life but nourishes and feeds, being an essential shelter in the return to the origins, not for death, but for eternal life diluted in the great unity, being therefore great, as big as the sea, or rather the great sea, which is the ocean. Whoever wants to be as it should be in existence or even correctly govern the world, must follow the model of the water in rivers and seas, as we read in chapter 66: Rivers and seas are greater than a hundred valleys Because they remain below them, and so they are princes, dominating waterfalls and streams. (江海所以能为百谷王者/以其善下之/故能为百故王)3 (Abreu,2013, 158-159) The wise man's behavior is distinguished by its malleability and spontaneity. He does not impose himself, which is why he is respected by everyone, only he should then govern, because he acts naturally, without oppressing, without hurting, letting everyone follow their course as freely as possible, as is reiterated in chapter 78: Nothing in the world is more malleable and flexible as for water, but in attacking what is hard and rigid nothing can surpass it and there is nothing to replace it. (天下莫柔弱於水/而攻堅強者莫之能先) (Ribeiro, 2004 160-161) Laozi's Taoist water is among the Five Chinese Elements (Water, Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal) the one that evokes great oceanic unity, source of life for everything that exists, but also of death, or rather, of return to origins and eternal life, when this image represents the philosophical principle Tao. And if water, fresh and salty, is the supreme good of the world, the Tao is the origin, the supreme good, including of Heaven. As a root or mysterious female (chap 6) it is the root of the cosmos as we know and experience it. He is a source of spiritual and material life, but so is water, since his model must be followed in all circumstances, from the material source of beings to complex human conduct. People who act correctly, and especially Taoist sages and saints, are aware of the physical and concrete model of water that helps them practice another invisible one, that of Tao. They will then be malleable and adaptable, capable of nourishing themselves from the inside and giving life to any form on the outside. You will know how to transform yourself to better nourish and vivify. The Taoist oceanic model differs from the one that inspired the Portuguese throughout history, who looked to the sea as their ocean. Taoist water is not challenging nor does it call for conquest, it does not have cables of storm or hope to bend, it does not require weapons or boats, nor maps, nor nautical instruments. It is the dominant, conquering element within all beings, who will adapt to this most malleable element, without needing to develop their inventive spirit. The philosophy it leads to does not ask for vigilance or a critical spirit, but adaptation to the world as it is and generosity to accept it with a minimum of suffering and a maximum of joy. item.title: Julie Oyang
item.description: Interview with James Yanzhao Xing, Chinese private collector living in Xi'an, specializing in Ancient Jade (Archaic Jade) Four years ago, in 2021, James inherited more than 300 pieces of antiques from his elderly father. The family heritage dates back to the Song dynasty (10th-13th centuries) and the collection includes exquisite jade items, porcelain, bronze wares, incense burners and high-value jewelry from various periods. During the turbulent war years, these treasures were buried in a hole in the backyard for decades. Now, through their interdisciplinary curatorial project, they are about to enter a dynamic dialogue with the worlds of fashion, art and sport. Joy: How did you feel when you received the family inheritance? I was completely surprised! My brothers and I had no idea that our family had such things. We were ignorant about our family history. Joy: Tell me about your family history. James: Our original surname was Zhao and we belonged to the imperial family of the Song dynasty. Our roots are in the heart of Chinese civilization. Chinese history has been complicated and turbulent, and my family has failed to preserve the details of our specific ups and downs. All I know is that in 1931, to escape the Japanese occupation, my grandmother took my father and other family members and together they walked to Chongqing in the south. My father was still a boy. To survive and take better care of her son and family, my grandmother decided to remarry into a local clan called the Xing. The Xing family accepted the proposal, as long as my grandmother paid them 300 taels of silver, a significant amount in wartime China. That's how we changed our imperial surname Zhao to Xing. After remarrying, my grandmother asked my father to dig a hole in the yard. That's where the family heirloom was stored, until my father decided to pass it on to me. My father didn't want to divide the collection between my brothers, as he knew I was the only one who could appreciate its true value. To repay my father's appreciation for me, I immediately gave my private collection a name: Jade Ambience, 琼华幸境 in Chinese. Joy: Why that name? James: I feel like I've always been lucky in life, like I've always been protected by some supernatural force with which I could cure strange illnesses and save people. You know, I love helping people and I can't stand seeing sadness and injustice in the world. Since he was a child, he saved lives during the annual floods of the Yangtze River in Chongqing. I didn't fear for my own life, because I knew I was protected. Will it be a gift? I would like to believe so. I even abandoned my career as a successful businessman and decided I wanted to be a soldier, so I could actually contribute to my country instead of earning a lot of money. I even turned down an opportunity to go to the USA and run a company there. That was in 1989. My experiences in the army made me stronger, both physically and mentally. I value life's experiences because they make me understand the human world better and give me positive energy to appreciate each day. In some inexplicable way, I attribute all of this to the jade items in my collection (laughs). JOy: In fact, Chinese people believe that jade stone radiates positive energy. Since ancient times, jade has been associated with protective power, healing power and immortality. What is the true value of your collection, in your opinion? As I said, jade has a very special place in Chinese culture. Jade symbolizes moral integrity and virtue, which is the stone's central symbolic value. Confucianism inextricably linked jade to the ideal of the “exemplary person” (junzi 君子), who should embody the virtues reflected in the physical qualities of jade, including benevolence, righteousness, wisdom, courage (“It is better to be a broken jade than an intact tile”) and purity. Jade served as a material expression of authority and was made into ritual objects used to communicate with divine forces and symbolized imperial power—most notably through the legendary Imperial Seal made of jade. For ordinary Chinese people, jade offers protection and good luck and has long been considered a talisman against evil forces. Jade carvings also carry auspicious meanings: bats for blessings, peaches for longevity, and fish for abundance. In ancient belief systems, jade was believed to preserve the body and soul after death. This concept found its ultimate expression in the jade burial suits of the Han dynasty, intricately assembled from thousands of pieces of jade to ensure immortality. Jade was also seen as the essence of the cosmos—a fusion of the vital energies of heaven and earth. The Chinese language is rich in jade-related expressions that convey admiration and virtue! Therefore, jade items are timeless symbols of love, symbolizing lasting and sincere affection. Today, jade remains a precious heirloom, a solid investment, and a powerful emblem of cultural identity — connecting contemporary Chinese to our heritage. In this way, jade contains old and new life! Jade is not just a precious stone full of vitality. It is a cultural landmark — a bridge between old China and new China. Joy: What do you want to do with your collection? James: Right now, I'm planning to organize a traveling exhibition in Beijing, Shanghai and maybe Macau. As I said before, jade is full of vitality. Jade is a bridge between ancient China and modern China. So I don't want to limit my collection to the usual antique circles. I'm thinking about doing cross exhibitions with fashion, art and sport. I want jade to have a lively dialogue with contemporary, young and modern Chinese audiences!

item.title: Australia | Twelve killed in attack during Jewish festival
item.description: At least twelve people died and many injured were transported to Sydney hospitals yesterday, after a shooting attack on the Australian beach of Bondi, while a Jewish celebration was taking place. “There are two people in police custody on Bondi beach”, reported the New South Wales State Police on its X account, which asks “the public to avoid the area”. Citing police sources, the AFP news agency reports that the attack caused ten deaths. The New South Wales ambulance service confirmed to ABC television that at least 16 people were transported to six hospital centers in the region. Several witnesses report that it was a shooting attack carried out by an as yet undetermined number of armed people, but the authorities have not confirmed this information either. A British tourist told French news agency AFP that he saw “two gunmen dressed in black and armed with semi-automatic rifles”. Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has already issued a statement lamenting the “shocking and distressing scenes” coming from Bondi and confirmed the existence of injuries. Part of the beach was the scene of a celebration of the Jewish festival of Hanukkah, which began yesterday and, although Australian authorities have not yet made any connection with the incident, the President of Israel, Isaac Herzog, denounced what he classified as a “vile terrorist attack against the Jews who were lighting the first candles” of the religious festival. "Our heart is with them. The heart of the entire nation of Israel beats strong at this precise moment, as we pray for the recovery of the injured, we pray for them and we pray for those who lost their lives," he said in an official statement.
