The absence was noted in the release of crime data for the months of January to September this year, which show the increase in sexual abuse of minors to almost double
The Government stopped publishing data on suicide cases in Macau, as well as attempts. The absence of these numbers was noted by the newspaper Cheng Pou when it released crime data for the months of January and September this year on Friday. The publication even questions whether “the data on suicide has become ‘the secret that cannot be said’ of the authorities, committed to building a happy Macau”, remembering that this data began to be released in 2015. Highlight is the fact that the Health Services also stopped publishing the statistics, something that was done every three months. In the case of the Security Secretariat, the data was monthly and was broken down by sex, age group and methods used. The lack of numbers comes after Macau broke records in terms of suicide cases in 2024, registering 90 deaths, 2.27 percent more than in 2023. Compared to 2022, the increase was 12.5 percent. Of the 90 cases, 48 ​​concerned male victims and 42 female victims, aged between 12 and 76 years. The most recent data, for the first half of this year, reveals 41 deaths by suicide and 101 attempts. In the release of crime statistics, on Friday, only one case of death by suicide appears in relation to an episode of homicide between brothers, which occurred in August this year, in the north zone. Here, the older brother jumped from the balcony, being suspected of having killed his younger brother due to financial disputes. Break in crime Looking at the crime panorama in general terms, there is a drop of 7.1 percent in the months under analysis, compared to the same period last year. The territory's authorities highlighted the sharp drop in computer crimes. The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, said that the drop is due to the “decreasing trend” of “crimes that attract more attention from society”, including serious violent crime, theft, robbery, fraud and computer crimes. In the first nine months of the year, 187 violent crimes were recorded, which represents a drop of 11 percent compared to the same period in 2024 (210). Thefts, robberies and frauds fell by 7.7, 5.9 and 23.6 percent, respectively. Computer crime, which recorded 770 cases in the first nine months of 2024, showed a decline of 52.1 percent in the period under analysis, with 369 cases. The decline in cases of fraud using telecommunications, cyber fraud and computer fraud, said Chan Tsz King, “reflects the effectiveness of the prevention and combat work carried out by the police, and the significant increase in public awareness about fraud prevention”, he said. The Government also highlighted that crime related to illicit gambling increased by 985 percent between January and September this year, with 394 more cases compared to the same period in 2024. The increase is due to the entry into force, in October last year, of the law to combat illicit gambling crimes, which introduced “the new crime of ‘exploitation of illicit exchange for gambling’ and expanded the scope of coverage of some crimes related to illicit gambling”. For the same reason, said the secretary, gambling-related crimes soared in the first three quarters of 2025 – 1,737 cases, 70.1 percent more than in the same period last year. In the past, the official said, fraud committed by people illegally exchanging money outside casinos “could not be identified as related to gambling”. “However, with the criminalization of ‘illegal money exchange’ and the improvement of legal provisions”, these cases “are now included in gambling crime statistics, thus increasing the number of crimes”, he indicated. More abuse of minors Chan Tsz King, who took office in October and presented the crime report for the first time on Friday, also referred to a 6.1 percent increase in crimes against the person, with child sexual abuse increasing by 86.7 percent, from 15 cases in the first nine months of 2024 to 28 cases in the same period this year. The secretary explained that these are essentially “voluntary sexual acts between people of the same age”, with “transmission of photographs and pornographic images”, without forgetting cases of “less serious sexual harassment”. “Cases involving people with family relationships were also identified, which deserves the attention of society”, said Chan Tsz King, who released data on awareness-raising actions on this problem: more than 70 activities carried out by the police, which saw the participation of more than 12,000 people, including students, guardians and teaching staff. Drug trafficking and sale and drug consumption, in turn, registered an increase of 37.1 percent, with 13 more cases, and 72.7 percent, eight more cases, respectively. According to the secretary's presentation, the 48 cases registered in the three quarters and the respective increase are due to “the discovery of several cases of cross-border drug trafficking through the reinforcement of internal and external police cooperation”, highlighting a case that occurred in September, when 31 kilos of cannabis flower worth 31.77 million patacas were seized. Chan Tsz King said that this was “the biggest case of cannabis smuggling seized in the history of Macau”. Between walls In the case of the crime of rape, there was a decline in the number of rape crimes, to a total of 24 cases, 40 percent less than in the same period of the previous year. The Secretary for Security added that “more than 70 percent of the victims were not residents of Macau”, and “the majority of these crimes occurred in hotel rooms”, while “a number of these involved pecuniary conflicts between the victims and the suspects, and it is not possible to rule out the hypothesis that some of the cases occurred in the context of a sexual transaction”. In this context, the secretary clarified that the police authorities have been “in close communication with the hotel sector”, and “police devices and inspections in peripheral areas of hotels and casinos” have been reinforced. Between January and September, more than 160 police actions were carried out to combat prostitution, with 192 people suspected of engaging in prostitution activity being intercepted. Furthermore, during the period in question, 17 cases of pimping or exploitation of prostitution were resolved, with the arrest of 26 suspects. Silence as always Questioned by Lusa during the press conference about the first case to be investigated in Macau within the scope of national security, the secretary made no comments. “The case (…) is being handled by judicial entities and, due to secrecy, it would not be appropriate for the Secretary of Security to comment”, added Chan Tsz King, who was a Public Prosecutor when former deputy Au Kam San was detained. At the end of July, the territory's police announced the arrest of Au Kam San, the first under the state security defense law, which came into force in 2009, with the scope being expanded 14 years later. The accusation is not yet known and there is no information about who will defend the former deputy. With Lusa

item.title: EU | New target to reduce 90% of pollutants by 2040
item.description: MEPs and countries from the European Union (EU) yesterday reached an agreement on a target to reduce 90 percent of polluting emissions by 2040, with a view to carbon neutrality in 2050, although new forms of flexibility are foreseen. “The co-legislators agreed on a target of a 90 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2040, compared to 1990 levels, with the aim of achieving climate neutrality in the EU by 2050”, is announced in a statement released in Brussels. After several hours of negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council thus reached, this morning, a provisional political agreement (which will have to be confirmed by both) on an amendment to the EU Climate Law, establishing a new intermediate and binding target for 2040, that of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions by 90 percent compared to 1990 levels. Even so, MEPs and countries agreed to introduce new forms of flexibility to meet the 2040 target, “believing that the green transition and European competitiveness must advance hand in hand”, according to the note. Under review Specifically, from 2036 onwards, up to five percentage points of emissions reductions (two more than the Commission's initial proposal) could come from high-quality international carbon credits, compatible with the Paris Agreement. In the case of Portugal, for example, this means that sustainable projects in countries such as Portuguese-speaking African Countries (PALOP) can count towards the Portuguese target. “Thanks to Parliament's insistence, additional safeguards were integrated, including the prohibition of financing projects in partner countries that contradict the Union's strategic interests”, highlights the European assembly. It is up to the European Commission to analyze different options for the role of international credits in future EU climate legislation to reach the 2040 target. Furthermore, the community executive will assess progress every two years, taking into account the most recent scientific data, technological advances and the EU's international competitiveness. "The review will analyze the situation of net removals at European level, comparing it with what is necessary to meet the 2040 target, as well as possible implementation difficulties and the potential to strengthen the EU's industrial competitiveness. Trends in energy prices and their impacts on companies and families will also be considered", according to the European Parliament. This will allow Brussels to modify the 2040 target or take additional measures to strengthen the support framework, for example to protect the EU's competitiveness, prosperity and social stability. Parliament will now vote on the informal agreement and the Council will also have to approve it, with the text coming into force 20 days after its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. The European Climate Law makes each country's effort to reduce its polluting emissions legally binding.

item.title: UCM | White Paper suggests methods to accelerate economic diversification
item.description: The “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, produced at the City University of Macau, refers to inequalities in the relationship between countries and concludes that “economic diversification has advanced at a slow pace”. Bárbara Morais, main writer of the document, explains the main conclusions of the analysis On December 3rd, a White Paper was launched that provides a look and analysis of the way in which cooperation in scientific and technological areas between China, Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries has been taking place, outlining some criticisms, not only on this topic, but also on the economic direction that the Macao SAR is taking. The document, entitled “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, was produced by the City University of Macau (UCM) and had Bárbara Morais, a doctoral student at the institution, as main writer. In an interview with HM, she describes that, in Macau, “economic diversification has advanced at a slower pace than desired, keeping the economy structurally dependent on gambling and tourism”. "The central message of the White Paper is clear: Macau needs to accelerate the transition to functions with greater added value. However, the current context offers a renewed window of opportunity. With the support of the Greater Bay Area and, very specifically, the Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin, Macau now has new structural opportunities to recover lost momentum and reposition itself, not just as a cultural bridge, but as a true platform for innovation", he said. Still on the territory, but in relation to Forum Macau, the “success in institutionalizing political dialogue” is mentioned, but the White Paper “points the finger at the insufficiency of execution mechanisms”. “To streamline the role of the Forum and transform it into a tool for tangible results, the White Paper advocates a paradigm shift: it is necessary to move from declarations of intent to technicality”, describes Bárbara Morais. The doctoral student suggests “the creation of specialized technical working groups, especially in the technological sphere, and the rigorous definition of performance indicators, such as the number of registered patents, startups created or joint research projects”. “At the same time, it is suggested to establish a common agenda focused on areas of the future, such as green energy, health, the maritime economy and artificial intelligence, subject to a periodic assessment of progress”, he also said. The place of arbitration Taking these meager developments into account, the White Paper suggests that Macau assert itself “as a center for technological arbitration and intellectual property governance”. HM questioned Bárbara Morais about what should be done in effective terms, taking into account the existence, for several years, of an arbitration center, and the fact that it has been a topic on the territory's political agenda for a long time. The doctoral student highlights that “in order for these ideas, debated for years, to stop being rhetoric and become reality, the Macao SAR needs to create a legal framework specialized in technological disputes aligned with the most demanding international standards”. "It is essential to attract international experts and arbitrators through competitive incentives and establish an arbitration center that enjoys recognition both in Portuguese-speaking countries and in the Greater Bay Area. The objective is to develop mediation, certification and management services for intellectual property assets, positioning Macau as a 'safe haven', neutral and efficient, for the resolution of international technological disputes", he added. Unequal cooperation In global terms, and with regard to cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries (PLP), the White Paper refers to “top planning” by Beijing for cooperation in universities and scientific research. However, planning “does not translate, linearly, into equally effective execution mechanisms on the ground, nor does it guarantee homogeneous results among the nine Portuguese-speaking countries”. Planning implies “clear guidelines, defined priorities and diplomatic instruments mobilized to guide this cooperation”, with policies such as “Made in China 2025” or the “Digital Silk Road”, which “integrate technological cooperation with the PLP into the very core of Chinese foreign policy and national innovation”, highlights the author. However, there are “inequalities, which are perhaps the most striking feature of this relationship”, as Bárbara Morais explains. “The current scenario reveals a profound asymmetry, characterized by a ‘bicephaly’ in cooperation. (…) The main scientific capabilities, the robust technological infrastructure and the volume of effective cooperation are overwhelmingly concentrated in Portugal and Brazil”. On the contrary, “Portuguese-speaking African countries (PALOP) and Timor-Leste have a significantly lower participation”. According to Bárbara Morais, the “disparity does not arise from a lack of political will, but rather from structural funding limitations, a shortage of qualified human resources and the fragility of local research institutions”. Thus, there is “two-speed cooperation, very asymmetrical within the Portuguese-speaking community itself”. The White Paper highlights the “historic crossroads” in relation to cooperation between China and the PLP, which means “the urgent need to move from potential to implementation” in this matter. "There are ambitious visions and strategic plans, but practical results remain below what is possible. To resolve this crossroads, the proposed path involves strengthening execution mechanisms, investing massively in talent and technical-scientific education, creating ecosystems of genuine collaborative innovation between China, Macau and the PLP, and, above all, having the courage to measure results and reformulate strategies based on empirical evidence, abandoning the discourse of circumstance in favor of economic and scientific pragmatism." Gaps in Africa Another of the conclusions of the White Paper is the “tenuity” of academic links with the African continent, which Bárbara Morais describes as a “fragile scenario”. “There is a triad of factors: the scarcity of installed scientific capacity, the chronic lack of funding and consistent mobility programs”, without forgetting “the absence of stable joint research structures”. “To bridge this gap and create a lasting critical mass, the White Paper is not limited to diagnosis, suggesting concrete measures such as the robust reinforcement of research grants, the creation of joint doctoral programs, the implementation of collaborative laboratories and the design of academic mobility mechanisms specifically oriented to the African reality”, he adds. The document also talks about the negative impact of “geopolitical asymmetries”, such as the “technological restrictions of the European Union and NATO on Portugal”. According to Bárbara Morais, “real and restrictive impacts” are at stake. "These limitations condition the participation of Portugal and, by extension, of other Portuguese-speaking actors that cooperate in a network with Lisbon, in high-technology projects that involve China. The impact is particularly sensitive in critical areas such as 5G telecommunications, defense, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity, creating barriers that require complex diplomatic navigation." New strategies The White Paper was developed at the UCM Research Institute on Portuguese-Speaking Countries, and written by Bárbara Morais with the participation of academic João Simões. The project is based on a review of academic literature on the topic and also on the results of the “Technological Cooperation Launch Seminar”, held on July 22, 2025 at UCM. The work analyzes areas such as “strategic evolution”, “institutional mechanisms”, “technological milestones” and “structural challenges”, aiming to “provide evidence-based strategies to transform the potential of the China-PLP partnership into a concrete reality, creating a new model of technological cooperation for the Global South”, says a statement from UCM.

item.title: Europe | Merz considers aspects of Trump's geostrategy unacceptable
item.description: The head of the German federal government, Friedrich Merz, declared yesterday that there are certain unacceptable points in the document on Defense and geostrategy of the North American Administration led by Donald Trump, from a European perspective. “I don’t see any need for Americans to want to save Democracy in Europe,” he said, on a visit to Rhineland-Palatinate (a southwestern state), which is home to several United States of America (USA) military bases. In a strategic document on US national security, released last week, there is a warning about the danger of “civilizational extinction” in Europe if “current trends” continue. Trump, in the preface, summarizes: “we put America first in everything we do”. “It is more than plausible that, in a few decades at most, the members of NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization) will become predominantly non-European”, he wrote, adding that “it is legitimate to question whether they will perceive their place in the World or their alliance with the USA, in the same way as those who signed the organization's charter”. The White House regrets European decisions that “undermine political freedom and sovereignty, the migration policies that are transforming the continent [Europe] and creating tensions, as well as the censorship of freedom of expression and the repression of political opposition, the drop in birth rates and the loss of national identities (…)”. Washington expresses the desire for “Europe to remain European, regain its civilizational self-confidence and abandon its fruitless obsession with regulatory suffocation.”

item.title: East Timor | Memories of a man's life reflect the resistance of a people
item.description: The book “Return to Uaidora, the childhood and youth of Domingos Gusmão” recounts the Timorese's testimonies about the years of Timor-Leste's resistance to the Indonesian occupation. The testimony was written in Macau by former resident and university professor Duarte Trigueiros. 50 years after the occupation, the author reminded HM of the work launched in 2022 This year has been marked by the celebrations of the 50th anniversary of the independence of many former Portuguese colonies. Timor-Leste went to one of these territories. However, shortly after the unilateral proclamation of independence, on November 28, 1975, there was a period of confrontation that culminated in the Indonesian occupation, on December 7 of the same year. This Sunday marks 50 years since the invasion that marked the fate of the young country. In connection with this date, the book “Regresso a Uaidora, the childhood and youth of Domingos Gusmão” was released in 2022, which reveals the story of the Timorese, who was a student in Macau and a student of the author Duarte Trigueiros, former economist and professor at the University of São José. HM spoke to the author about the reflection of the pain and struggle for self-determination of a people that can be seen in the life of a man and his family. "When I was teaching in Macau, I collected the testimony of this Timorese from Baucau. Domingos Gusmão, knowing that he had taught at the National University of Timor-Leste for several years, told me how he and his family lived through all these terrible events." This is how the book was born, with Trigueiros merely reporting the testimony, later corrected in partnership with Domingos Gusmão. The work only has an online version, but at the time of launch it had the support of Fundação Oriente in printing some copies. Matebian, East Timor Duarte Trigueiros, who lived in Macau for several years, came into contact with Domingos Gusmão during the Festa da Lusofonia, in 2015. "I went to the Timor-Leste tent and he told me that he had interesting things to tell me, but that he couldn't speak Portuguese well, and that he would like to leave his testimony in writing. At one point I proposed asking him questions from his childhood, about life in the village, and thus the book was born, with nine chapters.” The beginning of the work describes, “through the eyes of a child, the day-to-day life of farmers in the Baucau mountains in Timor-Leste, the determination in which they reacted to the invasion of their country in 1975 and the brutal repression that followed”. "The book follows not only his life, but also his family and the few who remained. In the end, there was practically no one left", describes Duarte Trigueiros. According to the work, Domingos Gusmão was born on November 1, 1969 in the village of Uaidora, belonging to the municipality of Baucau, the son of Julião, a farmer, and Juliana, a maid. "But only the place where I was born is correct. The date of birth is nothing more than a conjecture and the names that appear on the certificate as being my parents, Julião and Juliana, are also not those of my real father and mother, but of relatives who adopted me when I was an orphan. In fact, I am the son of Martinho Gusmão, whose code name was 'Maunoco' and he was the chief of the Uaidora village until his death in 1983; and my mother was Ricardina, Martinho Gusmão’s second wife, the one who gave him offspring.” This is how Domingos’ story begins. Going to Baucau The work recounts very difficult years, with thousands of Timorese fleeing into the bush to escape the Indonesians, organizing armed struggle. One of the chapters, highlights Duarte Trigueiros, reports how Domingos and his family "were deported and left without any type of support, without doctors or food. "A huge number of people died at that time, until the beginning of the 80s, and they [Dominicos Gusmão's family], already in the place where they were cultivating the land, began to have fruits from the land, and send children to school. This boy [Domingos Gusmão], during that time, started preparing to go to Baucau to study, something that was not easy, as it was necessary to find a place, and there were many children.” Domingos and Xanana Gusmão It was there that the family decided to leave the village and go to Baucau, finding jobs “at the service of the troops, judges, nurses and doctors”, which gave them their first contacts with the Timorese resistance. "He [Domingos Gusmão] began organizing what they called a clandestine front with his colleagues. The book reports all these adventures that clearly reveal how the resistance worked. This boy then felt the desire to continue his studies and applied to a Catholic seminary", recalled Duarte Trigueiros. The connection to the Catholic religion was not an accident. "The purpose was to go abroad, because the only thing that Indonesians really respected was the Catholic Church, they didn't respect anything else. And he left, spent a number of years training. He was in the Philippines, where he also participated in resistance activities, and returned as a priest, in 2012." Writing this book was important to Domingos Gusmão because he “wanted to mention the names of the [Timorese] commanders of the first phase, when the Indonesian troops entered through Baucau, towards the interior, and there were a large number of resistance commanders who resisted, almost without weapons, and were killed”. “When he spoke to me about this subject, he was very insistent, he told me ‘Write down the name of that commander.’ Everything so that the names would not be forgotten”, he recalled. "What he told me is that nowadays, in Timor-Leste, people are compensating the members of the resistance who are alive, but there are many dead who gave their lives for this and are being forgotten. But this book also talks about everything on a personal level, about what happened to the uncle, how the father died at that stage, thrown to the ground, with a gun butt, with kicks, because he refused to accept an order and they threw him to the ground. He was the head of the village and had to accept the order [of the Indonesians], but he refused”, highlighted Duarte Trigueiros. For the author, the work tells “a truer version” of what the Indonesian occupation was, and very specifically about the experiences of the town of Uaidora and the interior of the country. In the book, you can read Domingos' testimony about this phase of resistance in Baucau, starting in 1986. “I owe my enlistment in the resistance to the clandestine fronts and also to my colleague Domingos de Oliveira. (…) A few weeks later, on the 16th or 17th of September 1991, the centenary of the Dili cathedral was celebrated and young people were invited to participate. 14 left from Baucau. Buses full of teenagers and I was one of them. The next day, during the return trip, FRETILIN flags appeared and we all sang hymns to independence. As we passed through Manatuto, the troops ordered us to stop, but then they told us to continue; and at the entrance to Baucau, before the airport, the road was blocked and we were surrounded by a strong military device. There were only three assault cars!” Gusmão continues his account of this tense moment. "After having cornered us like this, the troops, with the assault vehicles on the right side, occupied the left side. The 14 trucks were lined up with the military device, which had its weapons in position, ready to fire. They were like a very long firing squad. There we stayed, with all those weapons pointed at us, in silence while time passed and nothing happened." Support from Portuguese Duarte Trigueiros and Domingos Gusmão kept in touch, but a stroke took away the Timorese's quality of life. "He hardly responds to my emails. Maybe he has a different outlook on life", confesses the author. Another perspective that the work gives, according to Trigueiros, is the position of the Portuguese authorities during the years of Indonesian occupation, dispelling the idea that there was abandonment after independence. "I simply show what Domingos told me, and he told me that many of the resistance commanders had been Portuguese soldiers and that, therefore, they knew how to use weapons. He also told me that they were extremely patriotic. There is a report that in the 90s they tried to get a satellite phone from Portugal to give to the resistance, and there are references to the support of the Portuguese Embassy in Manila. I think we looked good in the photograph", he concludes. Duarte Trigueiros taught in Timor between 2004 and 2009, where he found higher education very weak. "The students practically didn't know Portuguese and we had to teach in Portuguese. That alone was a huge effort. In general, the students were weak, they were very poorly prepared. The [educational] preparation of the Indonesians had been of a low level, as there was discrimination against students for being Timorese. The book describes this, how only good students had the right to move up, so to speak, and that didn't even mean going to university." Even so, Duarte Trigueiros highlights the training of “a good number of people, engineers, law graduates, economists”. “It took a lot of work and that was the great support that Portugal was able to give”, he added. Today, the former economist says that the Timorese look at the Portuguese with immense gratitude. "It's amazing, because when we go on a street with an Australian, they despise the Australian and don't talk to him, but with the Portuguese they shower him with all kinds of affection. This happens a lot in Timor-Leste", he concluded.

item.title: Evolution | African genomes point to the origins of the human species
item.description: Homo sapiens has existed for at least 300,000 years, but its exact origin remains unknown and a new study has ruled out the hypothesis that it evolved in East Africa and expanded south. The study, based on the analysis of ancient genomes of people who lived from the Stone Age – 10,200 years ago – to 150 years ago in southern Africa, argues that a group of individuals lived in partial isolation for several hundred thousand years. By analyzing their genomes, researchers found genetic adaptations that likely shaped H. sapiens as a species. Details of the study – the most comprehensive to date on ancient African DNA – conducted by researchers from Uppsala University (Sweden) and the University of Johannesburg, were published on Wednesday in the magazine “Nature”, reported the agency Efe. “We have long known that Southern Africa was inhabited (…). We can now demonstrate that Homo sapiens existed and evolved in Southern Africa over a long period and that this region played a significant role in human evolution, perhaps the most important of all”, highlighted Mattias Jakobsson, geneticist at Uppsala University and main author of the study. The team analyzed the ancient genomes of 28 individuals from southern Africa and compared them with those of their contemporaries from other parts of the world. They discovered that the Stone Age inhabitants of southern Africa lived in isolation for a long period. “This group appears to have remained genetically isolated for at least 200,000 years, and it was only around 1,400 years ago that clear traces of genetic flow within this group began to emerge, when DNA from individuals from East and West Africa began to appear in individuals from Southern Africa,” explained Jakobsson. Although no new groups migrated to southern Africa until about 1,400 years ago, genetic data suggests that members of the southern population migrated north during certain climatic periods. In fact, genetic material — dating back to around 8,000 years ago — from this southern population has been found in individuals from present-day Malawi, making it possible that southern migrations also occurred earlier. Techniques and variations A large part of the human remains analyzed were found in the Matjes River Rock Shelter (South Africa), an archaeological site with remains dating back approximately 10,000 to 1,500 years. This site also revealed different tools from each historical period, made with different techniques. However, the individuals are genetically practically identical throughout the entire period, that is, there is no evidence of immigration or population exchange, “exactly the opposite of what happened in Europe, where cultural changes tend to coincide with population migrations”, analyzed Jakobsson. In the study, researchers identified 79 DNA variants unique to Homo sapiens, distinct from those found in Neanderthals, Denisovans, chimpanzees and gorillas. Seven of these variants, related to kidney function, were “clearly overrepresented”. The authors believe that these variants are linked to the unique human ability to cool the body through sweat, which requires a good ability to regulate the body's water balance. They also found variants involved in the immune system and neuronal growth. More than 40 percent of these variants are associated with neurons and brain growth, suggesting a role in cognitive evolution. Additionally, several genes have been linked to attention, a mental ability that may have evolved differently in Homo sapiens compared to Neanderthals and Denisovans.

item.title: Light Rail | Qingmao will be a hub for several lines
item.description: The Qingmao Light Metro station will be added to connect different lines, meaning that the cost of the works has risen to MOP7.59 billion, compared to MOP3.04 billion originally. According to the Chinese channel Rádio Macau, the information is contained in the report on the Budgetary Execution of the Administration's Development Investment and Expenditure Plan (PIDDA), in which the East Line extension project appears with a new name. The new name identifies the station as the connection point between the Eastern Line and the Citizens' Sports Garden on the Old Canídrome Lot. The name change was identified in the Legislative Assembly, within the scope of the work of the Monitoring Committee for Public Finance Affairs, led by deputy Song Pek Kei. According to the president of the commission, who cited explanations from the Government, the number of stations will be increased from one to two, which combined with the costs of works, materials and systems to be installed, will increase the cost to 7.59 billion patacas.

item.title: Administration | Wong Sio Chak inaugurates Sónia Chan and Lo Pin Heng
item.description: The Secretary for Administration and Justice, Wong Sio Chak, presided yesterday morning at the inauguration ceremony of the new Director of Identification Services (DSI), Sónia Chan, and the new Director of the Legal and Judiciary Training Center, Lo Pin Heng. According to a statement issued by Wong Sio Chak's office, the government official “fully recognized the vast management experience and excellent leadership capacity of the two directors, highlighting their situational awareness and ability to execute”. On the day of the inauguration, the appointments were also made official through orders published in the Official Bulletin. Lo Pin Heng's service commission began yesterday and lasts for a year, similar to Sónia Chan's appointment as head of DSI. Wong Sio Chak urged DSI staff under the leadership of Sónia Chan to deepen innovation in reform, improve service to the public and respond to the development needs of the Greater Bay Area and the Hengqin Cooperation Zone. Regarding Lo Poin Heng, Wong Sio Chak hopes that under his leadership, the Legal and Judicial Training Center will provide more professional, quality and appropriate training to the Government, judicial bodies and the legal sector.

item.title: FAOM | New leadership led by Lam Lon Wai wants more patriotism
item.description: Promoting patriotism is the top priority of the new leadership of the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau, which will be led by deputy Lam Lon Wai Patriotism is the main priority of the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau (FAOM) for the coming years. The guarantee was left by Lam Lon Wai, who on Tuesday was elected as the new president of the board, after the first ordinary meeting of the FAOM board. Speaking to the newspaper Ou Mun, Lam Lon Wai stated that he will continue to promote the association's “glorious tradition of love for the country and Macau”, uniting workers in supporting the governance of the Macao SAR, in accordance with the laws in force. The president of the association also pointed out that he will focus on improving FAOM's services, in order to contribute to the “practice of the ‘One Country, Two Systems’ principle”, while increasing the “attraction, cohesion and service capacity” that the association provides. In relation to the remaining members of the association, at a lower hierarchical level compared to Lam Lon Wai, Kong Ioi Fai was elected president of the association's administration. Although he is not a deputy, Kong was the representative of the FAOM list, the Union for Development, in the last legislative elections held on September 14th. Regarding the goals for this mandate, Kong Ioi Fai indicated that the objectives include defending labor rights, increasing participation in governance, bridging the gap between the population and the Government, and also promoting a more harmonious society. The association also promises to work to implement new unions, in light of the new law. Patriotism in companies Kong Ioi Fai also revealed that the association will focus on promoting patriotism in the labor sector, hoping to create a strong patriotic culture in companies. This commitment involves developing manuals and content for workers on patriotism. The official also revealed that the association will continue to organize professional skills competitions and award activities, to highlight employees considered to be excellent in different areas. At the same time, the new management will organize more classes on artificial intelligence and cross-border e-commerce, to train the qualified staff needed for Macau's economic diversification. Kong Ioi Fai also highlighted that FAOM will explore Zone A of the New Urban Landfills and provide more social support. In relation to the remaining positions of the new FAOM board, the president of the previous board, Ho Sut Heng, was elected as president of the Supervisory Board. Some of the most popular members of recent years are retained in the new leadership, such as current deputies Ella Lei, Leong Sun Iok, Leong Pou U and former deputies Lei Chan U and Lee Chong Cheng. The new management will take office on January 20th.

item.title: Government | Secretaries committed to complying with Xi’s instructions
item.description: In the aftermath of the assessment of a year of governance presented by Sam Hou Fai in Beijing, the holders of the main public positions promised their commitment to articulating with the 15th five-year plan. Furthermore, they committed to guiding the course of Macau's development through the “important instructions” given by Xi Jinping The entire government team, and other holders of the main positions such as the Commissioner against Corruption, or the MSAR Prosecutor, issued statements yesterday demonstrating their commitment to complying with the guidelines given by President Xi Jinping during the presentation of the balance sheet of the first year of governance of the Executive led by Sam Hou Fai in Beijing. Even before arriving in Macau yesterday afternoon, the Chief Executive “expressed his sincere gratitude to the President for the full recognition of the work of the MSAR government, as well as for the valuable guidance and important instructions”. Sam Hou Fai stressed that the Government will “seriously” study and understand the guidelines given by Xi Jinping, “as well as firmly implement them” in next year’s Lines of Government Action. It is recalled that Xi Jinping indicated that Sam Hou Fai led the new Government of the Macao SAR in resolute advancement and pragmatic action, in the firm defense of the country's sovereignty, security and development interests, “fully recognizing the work carried out by the Chief Executive and the Government of the Macao SAR”. The Chinese President stressed that governance must be linked to the 15th Five-Year Plan, “insisting and improving the predominance of Executive power, solidly promoting the development of adequate diversification of the economy, constantly increasing the efficiency of governance and better integrating the national development situation and serving it”. Widespread enthusiasm The reactions of all secretaries followed in a succession of statements. The Secretary for Administration and Justice, Wong Sio Chak, “stated that the important instructions given by President Xi Jinping guided Macau's development path”, and that all his staff are “very enthusiastic” and committed to implementing the guidelines. Like all secretaries, Wong Sio Chak guaranteed that “the Administration and Justice area will act proactively in conjunction with the country's 15th Five-Year Plan”, and continue to deepen the reform of public administration, promote electronic governance and improve the functioning of public services. The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture stated that Xi Jinping's “important guidelines” reinforced confidence and were a “great stimulus for the team” under her supervision. Lam added that the President's instructions “are far-sighted, presenting a strong political, ideological, strategic and guiding dimension”, which will be taken as a “guide for action”. In the same vein, the Secretary for Transport and Public Works stated that the 15th National Five-Year Plan systematically outlines a grand project for national development over the next five years”. Raymond Tam Vai Man highlighted the provisions on optimizing the regional economic layout and the Greater Bay Area, which “provide fundamental guidance for work in the area of Transport and Public Works”. transport infrastructures and expanded urban space through landfills and urban renewal. Guardians of the country The Secretary for Economy and Finance, Anton Tai Kin Ip, also stated that he will implement President Xi Jinping's important guidelines. Furthermore, he guaranteed that “the functions of ‘a center, a platform, a base’ will be consolidated, taking advantage of Macau’s unique advantage as a ‘precision interlocutor’ between China and Portuguese-speaking countries to promote cooperation with these countries”. The secretary added that his authority is committed to expanding international exchanges, “well narrating the Macau chapter of the Stories of China”. In turn, the Secretary for Security committed to “firmly safeguarding the sovereignty, security and development interests of the State, defining the direction under the leadership of the 15th Five-Year Plan, preparing for adversities in prosperous times”. The intensification of prevention and reduction of the effects of natural disasters was also highlighted by Chan Tsz King, who committed to acting “by contributing to the construction of a strong country and to the great cause of national rejuvenation with Chinese-style modernization”. Another priority advanced by Chan Tsz King was the facilitation of border crossings, with particular focus on the connection between Macau and Hengqin. The director-general of the Customs Services (SA), Adriano Marques Ho, assured that, “as guardians of national security”, he will “unswervingly implement the requirements of the “general perspective of national security”, combating “severely” all activities that threaten national security. The official added that the SA is “burdened with the heavy responsibility of safeguarding the economic order of the Macao SAR.” The Commissioner against Corruption, Ao Ieong Seong, chose to highlight that the 15th Five-Year Plan requires lucidity and firmness in the fight against corruption and abuses of power. Upon arrival During the presentation to Xi Jinping of the balance of his governance, Sam Hou Fai realized the great importance and concern that the Chinese President and the Central Government attach to the development of Macau, said the Chief Executive upon arrival in the Macao SAR, still at the airport. The local official reiterated his “sincere thanks” for Beijing’s support and assured that he will unite and lead all sectors of society to study, implement and fully execute Xi Jinping’s “important” speeches and instructions, according to the Chinese channel Radio Macau. Sam Hou Fai also stated that the guidelines indicated by the Chinese President will guide the planning of the Executive's key tasks for next year and beyond. According to the Chief Executive, the Chinese leader called for improvements in the legal system and law enforcement mechanisms to safeguard national security.

item.title: Mental health | New Youth calls for investment in pets
item.description: The New Chinese Youth Association of Macau advocates investing in the “pet economy” as a way of dealing with young people’s mental problems and encouraging the development of open-air markets. The position was taken yesterday, after the presentation of a study by the association on the development of Macau's markets, cited by the newspaper Ou Mun. The study was based on 644 surveys, with people aged between 18 and 44, and concluded that 56.1 percent believe that the current model of development of traditional markets is the most correct. Furthermore, around 71.1 percent of respondents believe that more local brands focused on outdoor markets should be created, driven and promoted by young entrepreneurs. In view of the conclusions, the association represented by Kuok Meng Chit, vice-president, defended the Government's greater focus on measures to promote the "pet economy in local open-air markets. This investment is also seen as a way of promoting the mental health of younger people. Since the Covid-19 pandemic, Macau has been dealing with an increase in suicide attempts and suicides, with a major impact on younger people, which has led the authorities to stop publishing statistics. As part of the “pet economy”, the association asked for more space in open-air markets for canines and felines and also services such as animal-themed spaces and the possibility of renting carts to walk animals. With these ideas in mind, the association believes that “a high-quality social environment where people and pets coexist” will be created and that the “pet economy will be a new driving force for the development of Macau’s market economy”.

item.title: Traffic | UMTEC pays 9.22 million to Chongqin experts
item.description: The research company controlled by the University of Macau once again used the services of the Chongqing City Traffic Planning Study Institute and the Chongqing Sustainable Development of Resources and Economy Research Association within the scope of the General Planning of Traffic and Land Transport of Macau UMTEC, a research company controlled by the University of Macau, will pay 9.22 million patacas to two institutions in Chongqin, as part of the work to review the General Planning of Traffic and Land Transport in Macau. Information about the review of the plan that is in force until 2030 was released through the portal of the Directorate of Public Supervision and Management Services (DSSGAP). The works were awarded on December 9th and the Interior entities involved are the Chongqing City Traffic Planning Study Institute and the Chongqing Sustainable Development of Resources and Economy Research Association. These institutions were also involved in the creation of the plan, in 2022, which was subsequently subject to a public consultation. The services provided by the two institutions to the University of Macau company include assisting in aspects such as analyzing transport models, evaluating the effectiveness of planning and formulating proposals for optimizing current infrastructure. The contract provides for the provision of services until March 2027, that is, a service lasting practically two years. The amount paid by DSAT to UMTEC was not found yesterday, at closing time at HM, on the DSAL portal in the direct adjustments or awards area. Expected review The revision of Macau's General Traffic and Land Transport Planning had been planned since 2022, when the current plan came into force, at the time with the aim of developing a traffic infrastructure in the city to integrate Macau into the Greater Bay Area. The review will involve measuring the evolution of some indicators of traffic and transport policies such as the rate of sharing of public transport, average speed of circulation during rush hours, degree of satisfaction in relation to public transport, emission of polluting gases by land transport, rate of road accidents or the annual growth rate of motor vehicles. Also in 2030, when the final year of the plan's implementation is reached, a new evaluation is planned, which should also count on the contribution of the Chongqing City Traffic Planning Study Institute and the Chongqing Sustainable Development of Resources and Economy Research Association. These two institutions were also involved in the initial work, although at that time the amount received for the work provided to UMTEC was never made public. The matter was addressed by deputy José Pereira Coutinho in a written questioning, at the end of 2022, with DSAT admitting that it was unaware of the amount paid. The only certainty in advance was the fact that UMTEC received 20 million patacas for the work.

item.title: Tourism | Visitor forecast maintained at 39 million
item.description: The director of Tourism Services, Helena de Senna Fernandes, yesterday reiterated the estimate that by the end of the year the territory should receive around 39 million tourists. The statements were made by Senna Fernandes on the sidelines of the Global Tourism Economy Forum. According to official data, by the end of November, 36.5 billion tourists arrived in the territory, which means that an additional 2.5 million people should visit Macau throughout this month. Regarding the number of international tourists, according to the Ou Mun newspaper, the number is expected to reach 80 percent of pre-pandemic levels. Regarding the future, Senna Fernandes hopes that more tourists can be attracted to the territory given the possibility of greater cooperation with interior cities in the Greater Bay Area.

item.title: Lessons from 2025 for the Decade
item.description: (Continuation of the article published on December 11) In the security sector, the world will face complex challenges. Terrorism could take on new forms, using digital technologies and artificial intelligence. Cybersecurity will become a priority, with digital attacks on critical systems posing significant risks. It is estimated that by 2030 the global costs of cyber attacks could exceed US$10 billion annually. On a military level, geopolitical tensions between the United States and China could intensify. The Middle East will continue to be a focus of instability. Between 2026 and 2030, social and cultural scenarios will assume a determining role in shaping the global future. International migration will continue to be one of the most striking phenomena, driven by armed conflicts, economic inequalities and climate change. It is estimated that hundreds of millions of people may be in a situation of international or internal mobility, either in search of better living conditions or out of need for survival. Europe will face migratory pressures from Africa and the Middle East, with hundreds of thousands of people seeking refuge in countries such as Italy, Greece, Spain and Germany. This flow will require more robust integration policies, but it could also generate social and political tensions, fueling populist and nationalist discourses. In the United States, immigration will continue to be a central issue, with restrictive policies causing social tensions and protests, but also with the need for labor in sectors such as agriculture, construction and services. In Latin America, internal migration will intensify due to extreme climatic phenomena, such as floods and droughts, forcing millions of people to move from rural areas to cities. In Africa, desertification and armed conflicts in the Sahel could displace more than 20 million people, creating large-scale humanitarian crises. Urbanization will be another central phenomenon. By 2030, more than 65% of the world's population will live in urban areas, with megacities growing rapidly. Cities such as Lagos, Kinshasa, Mumbai, São Paulo and Jakarta could exceed 30 million inhabitants, facing challenges in infrastructure, housing, transport and sanitation. Accelerated urbanization will bring opportunities for economic and cultural dynamism, but also risks of inequality and social exclusion. Cities will need to invest in sustainable solutions, such as efficient public transport, affordable housing and waste management. The digitalization of cities, using smart technologies, can improve the quality of life, but will require inclusion policies to prevent vulnerable populations from being excluded. Demographic transformations will be equally decisive. Population aging in Europe, Japan and South Korea will require health and long-term care policies, with an impact on pension systems and fiscal sustainability. It is estimated that, by 2030, more than 25% of Europe's population will be over 65 years old, creating productivity and financing challenges for social systems. In contrast, Africa and parts of Asia will have growing young populations, with millions of people entering the job market. This phenomenon could be an opportunity for economic dynamism, but also a risk of instability if sufficient jobs are not created. India, for example, will have more than 1.5 billion inhabitants in 2030, with a young population that could drive growth, but will require massive investments in education and training. China will face the challenge of an aging population, with more than 400 million people over the age of 60 in 2030, which could limit economic dynamism and increase pressure on healthcare and pension systems. Cultural scenarios will also transform. Digital globalization will continue to spread cultural values ​​and practices, but also generate tensions between local traditions and external influences. Music, cinema and literature will circulate increasingly intensely, creating a hybrid global culture. However, movements asserting identity and valuing local cultures will gain strength, seeking to preserve traditions and resist cultural homogenization. Cultural diversity will be both a wealth and a challenge, requiring policies of inclusion and respect for difference. Migration, urbanization and demographic transformations will interact with environmental and technological phenomena. Cities will have to adapt to extreme weather phenomena, such as floods and heat waves, which will affect millions of people. Climate migration will become a reality, with entire populations moving due to rising sea levels and desertification. Accelerated urbanization will require technological solutions, such as smart cities and sustainable infrastructure, but also social policies to ensure inclusion. Demographic transformations will create new balances of power, with Africa and Asia gaining demographic and economic weight, while Europe and Japan will face aging challenges. In summary, the period between 2025 and 2030 can be described as a critical transition phase, in which the events of 2025 acted as catalysts for structural changes that manifested themselves in different dimensions. The global economy entered a cycle of moderate recovery, but with persistent risks. International politics was marked by polarization and geopolitical tensions, with the United States and China competing for technological and industrial leadership, and the Middle East remaining a focus of instability. The environment has revealed the urgency of the energy transition and climate adaptation, with extreme phenomena affecting millions of people. Technology has transformed economies and societies, creating opportunities and risks. Education and health required inclusive and innovative policies. Security has become a priority, with cyberattacks and digital terrorism posing significant risks. The social and cultural scenarios revealed the importance of migration, urbanization and demographic transformations. The future will depend on the ability to articulate national interests with collective responsibilities, building a balance between competitiveness and solidarity. If countries are able to invest in responsible innovation, inclusive education and energy sustainability, it will be possible to build a fairer, sustainable and inclusive future. Otherwise, the risk of prolonged stagnation and worsening inequalities will remain high. The period between 2025 and 2030 will therefore remain a decisive moment, in which humanity was called to choose between cooperation and fragmentation, between the courage to move forward and the risk of remaining a prisoner of its own contradictions.

item.title: My mouth is a blackhead
item.description: «… In your broken mouth, carnations grow, wither, leafless carnations in my chest» It was 1968 and Adriano sang the prophecy. Adriano Correia de Oliveira, the most expressive player of our times whose brief life has not been forgotten by many. It was a modeling presence that offered us, his almost visionary voice only took shape years later when life did not contemplate much more merit for having been a song of full dawn, and left us left to the sting of the speculative interventionism of occasional voices. That's why in times of flower wars, he still sings, and enchants all those who in their present bring us a future. Adriano is the name of the Emperor, and he also had that clear and imperturbable profile, serious and distinct, he knew how to look at him well, and it was on a clear April morning that he was born with the tone of Spring in the grace of a field of flowers; he was a jester, very different from a singer, he will forever be the most eloquent of song writers with something like a prophet and a lord full of discipline and nostalgia, those beings that do not exist, but exist forever in our imagination; This Adriano who tells us, following the song sung, that: «the heart only leaves its leaves if its roots rot/sad destiny of us, of the people of my country» But, “another carnation is the heart/ leafless in your chest” was a great interpreter of the song and a full herald of tomorrows. All these people do not deserve flowers, which they give and contemplate in the initiatory cycle of promises, in the germinal conquests of love, in the powerful saps of tenderness and in the social cycles of great achievements, these people do not deserve flowers. Plucked from the earth. There are wars of Rosemary and Marjoram, a comedy of deceptions by António José da Silva in the eighteenth century, our “Jew”, but the vegetal interpretation will now give rise to carnival puns between roses and carnations, which is no different from the author's humorous purpose. Often the most ferocious beings opt for singular things of icy whiteness, fogs and white roses, they are exclusively purists in their approach to matter and in the reflections of the very clear ornamentations, but none of this corresponds to the glimpse of Supraconsciousness on the other side of the portal. They are like that because yes, but never sensitive or fraternal, red, loving and intense like the scarlet beings of generous affirmation. Roses in winter, Dom Dinis had already suspected, but anyway, whoever plants pine forests, adds rose bushes to them, and miracles are always welcome, and even so, the most enlightened king let it pass as a sign of love, except that he would die in the middle of winter with doubts about his “pink green flowers” ​​but never apologizing to the superlative act of a royal belief. Unfortunately, we no longer have him among us to say about his lordship the strange things that happened to him, but let us never doubt his mouth like a nail broken into summer loves as red as his ardor. At that time we would have an intoxicating Hadrian and a king with recitatives and carnations in his mouth, and all the beauty that comes apart and begins again, in the kisses that we give only in the time of all the flowers.

item.title: Campbell's Soup
item.description: Robert Garza, a former cybersecurity analyst at Campbell's Soup, a well-known food brand sold in Macau and Hong Kong, filed a lawsuit in Michigan court, USA, claiming to have a recording of a meeting with Martin Bally, the company's vice president of information technology, held in November 2024, to discuss compensation. In the recording, Bally is heard saying that Campbell's Soup food is "sold to the poor" and is "highly processed", also stating that the chicken in the soup is "3D printed" and that "he would never buy it." Robert Garza is using the recording as evidence in this lawsuit, accusing the company of unfairly firing him because he found his comments challenging. The case is currently under trial. After checking the recording, Campbell’s Soup Company determined that these remarks were “vulgar, offensive and false,” and fired Bally last November and publicly apologized. Campbell's Soup is sold around the world and this incident, which occurred at the company's US headquarters, has significant implications. We can comment in depth on this news from multiple perspectives, from employment to business, including the food industry and the public. Firstly, from an industrial relations point of view, a senior employee tells an intermediate employee that the product they sell is “poor man's food”, which affects the company's image. The mid-level employee's complaint, which resulted in dismissal, demonstrates that the company's complaints mechanism is ineffective. Employees who complain put their jobs at risk. This form of management reduces employee loyalty, nullifies the company's long-term development potential and offers nothing positive. Ultimately, it forces employees to resign or report the situation to government entities or the press, escalating the conflict between the company and workers. The smooth functioning of companies depends on competent and loyal employees, they are their most important intangible asset, whatever the business area. In this case, although Bally was fired, the company needs to rethink its complaints mechanism. For example, they could be addressed directly to the Board of Directors, which would restore employee confidence and help with more effective management. Consumers are not interested in an employee being fired, but they are interested in discussing whether the company uses “3D printed chicken” in its food. Campbell’s Soup clarified that its chicken comes from traditional suppliers and is not “lab-grown” meat. "The label “bio-engineering” refers to the use of genetically modified technologies in some ingredients of plant origin, such as corn and soy. This is a common practice in the US food industry and is completely different from “cell-cultured meat”. To guarantee Campbell Soup's commercial reputation and product value, these clarifications must be accompanied by new sales and crisis management strategies. This involves reinforcing the company's long-term social responsibility, increasing the transparency of the production process and the acceptance of external inspections of ingredients to check for the presence of genetically modified components. All of this tests the decision-making ability and risk management ability of Campbell Soup management. On the other hand, “3D printed chicken” has once again reawakened the public’s long-standing concerns about the modern food industry. Consumers are concerned about whether mass-produced food is excessively processed, whether the origin of the products is clear and also about the effects they may have on health. This incident has once again led consumers to discuss these issues. The impact will be greater the greater consumers' concerns. Perhaps the company could consider hiring an external entity to conduct a survey to assess the level of consumer concern and then develop strategies to reduce it. For American society, Campbell’s Soup, which provides convenient and affordable food, has long had the image of a “family friendly” and “comforting” brand. The statement “food for the poor” insults consumers. People on low incomes have limited financial resources and rely on processed foods, which raises the question of the relationship between mass-produced foods and low income levels. This reveals that Americans' food choices are closely related to their finances. This phenomenon exposes the impotence of low-income Americans in choosing food and paints a embarrassing picture of a developed country. What is at the heart of this issue is the fact that a top manager at Campbell minimized public confidence in the company's product, causing a rupture between internal statements and consumer confidence. It represents a situation in which the “brand myth was built in the kitchen but collapsed in the boardroom”, a question of business ethics and not product quality. How this scandal will affect sales and the brand will depend on whether Campbell is able to successfully maintain its image as a familiar and comforting product, on consumers' memories, but also on their skepticism towards mass-produced foods, the actions of competitors, etc. In addition to resolving the crisis in the domestic market, the dimension of confidence in foreign markets, as important commercial destinations for Campbell’s Soup, cannot be ignored. In the age of the internet, events that occur in one place cross the world in an instant. If Campbell’s Soup does not consider the reactions of foreign consumers, it will be carrying out inadequate crisis management. item.title: General and surreal strike
item.description: A couple who are members of a union belonging to CGTP-Intersindical found themselves in a dilemma on the 11th, the day of the general strike, before leaving home. The problem was wanting to go to the demonstration organized to protest against the absurd proposal of the Montenegro Government regarding a possible new Labor Law, a general strike that had not brought together the UGT and the CGTP for many years. The dilemma was precisely related to the general strike. The couple, residing in Amadora, did not have any transport to travel to the center of Lisbon. His best neighbor had also decided not to go to the demonstration because the Metropolitano was on full strike. Thousands of workers were prevented from going to the demonstration due to lack of transport. Surrealism was in sight. The desire to protest, yes. Like, impossible. More surreal was the fact that the drivers of dozens of buses that the union centers rented to transport protesters had to work on a day of general strike, political Portugal is actually divided in half. On the one hand, conservatives and neo-fascists. On the other, the democratic and radical left. A sad division for those who want a better country and a reduction in the number of Portuguese living on the edge of poverty. The union centrals announced that the general strike was resounding, the best ever and with an unusual turnout of around 80 percent. The strike paralyzed air, rail, road, sea and river transport, as well as schools, daycare centers, hospitals, health centers, homes for the elderly, day centers, courts, universities and museums. The Montenegro Government came, with an air of contempt and arrogance for carrying out the general strike, to say that participation was low and that it would not have exceeded five percent. And his demagoguery prevailed when he “ordered” the television channels he controls to clearly show that at Autoeuropa there were a lot of workers not joining the general strike. The custom of numbers. For some, excellent. For others, a fiasco. The truth is that the general strike affected thousands of Portuguese people, in one way or another. The most important thing wasn't even the general strike. What is at stake is the widespread protest, including by some former PSD and CDS leaders, against the absurd and harmful content of the government proposal for a new Labor Law. The concern that has grown the most in company surveys is the lack of workers, many areas of activity face serious difficulties with the lack of qualified personnel and limitations on the recruitment of foreign labor, putting the objectives of the PRR at risk. In a context of labor shortages, real wages have grown in recent years above inflation, with emphasis on the construction sector, with appreciations above eight percent. Faced with this scenario, what did the Government decide in its ideological fury? Opening an incomprehensible social conflict around labor laws, which have already been profoundly revised several times this century. Nothing has been noticed about the Government's negotiating openness regarding the main themes of its proposal. Obviously, after four months of the Government turning a blind eye, a general strike had to be organized. A setback in labor pacifism is that the Government intends to allow for the possibility of dismissal without due process or just cause in companies of up to 50 workers, with the exemption from reinstatement if the dismissal is considered illegal by the court, the possibility of hiring in outsourcing the day following the collective dismissal, with an individual time bank, with a fixed-term contract for life, with the possibility of professional reclassification with a salary reduction, with the obligation for the children's parents to work on the weekends or with the decriminalization of undeclared and paid work under the table. These are some of the Government's “innovative” proposals, which at no time agreed to back down, but which in no way contribute to competitiveness, digital modernization and worker qualifications. After months of hypocrisy in dialogue and innocent lamentations about an “untimely” strike, Montenegro came to mix the threat about compliance with minimum services, and the terrible economic impact of the general strike. Simply nonsense with a wave of demagogy of promises about salaries that wouldn't even remind the unions of requests from Santa Claus... Even Bagão Félix and Silva Peneda have already recognized the inopportunity and unbalanced nature of the reform of labor legislation. And these personalities are not trade unionists or socialists, much less attended protest demonstrations or participated in strikes. The most surreal thing about all this is that the Government will hope that after having forgotten the general strike and after Christmas, it will be able to impose the crushing machine that will lead to Portuguese workers losing rights like they never dreamed of. All that remains is for the PSD/Chega alliance to announce that the democratic regime will also be the target of a labor reform…

item.title: Ivo M. Ferreira presents new film about terrorist group FP-25
item.description: It’s called “Global Project” and it’s the new film by Ivo M. Ferreira, a Portuguese director who previously lived in the territory. The presentation to the world of cinema is scheduled to take place at the Rotterdam International Film Festival, in January, which takes place in the Netherlands. The feature film is part of the “Big Screen” competition, whose narrative is “anchored in the early 1980s, when Portugal was the scene of attacks and robberies perpetrated by the 25 de Abril Popular Forces (FP-25)”. Ivo M. Ferreira's project, described by the festival as a political thriller “set in the turbulent years after the 'Carnation Revolution'”, features actors such as Jani Zhao, Rodrigo Tomás, José Pimentão, Gonçalo Waddington, Isac Graça, João Catarré, Ivo Canelas, Hugo Bentes, Isabél Zuaa, later giving rise to a series for RTP. According to the producer, the film “Projecto Global” will premiere in Portuguese cinemas on April 23rd of next year. The story focuses on Lisbon in 1980, when Rosa, Jaime and their FP-25 comrades “slide into an armed spiral where morale unravels, loyalty falters and each step opens a deeper abyss”. “Apart from themselves and with the dreams of the past in ruins, they no longer recognize the country they are crossing, and even less the people they have become”, describes the synopsis. Ivo M. Ferreira is also linked to the local cinema scene, having directed the feature film “Hotel Império” in Macau in 2016, starring Margarida Vila-Nova. His film, “Letters from War”, was also shown in Macau. Salvador's debut Another Portuguese film premiering at the Rotterdam film festival is “A Providência e a Guitarra”, by João Nicolau, having its world premiere here, outside of competition. This is a project that was born from a short story by writer Robert Louis Stevenson, and is performed by Pedro Inês, Clara Riedenstein, Isac Graça, Jenna Thiam, Américo Silva and musician Salvador Sobral. Shot in the summer of 2024, the film is presented as “a dive into the hardships and delights of artistic life and an exploration of its consequences” on marital and social relationships, and marks Salvador Sobral's debut in cinema. “A Providência e a Guitarra” is produced by O Som e a Fúria. In Rotterdam, the program for short and medium-length films will also include the short films “O”, by actress and director Francisca Alarcão, an experimental fiction about an aversion to navels, and “Computer”, by visual artist Alice dos Reis, which “intertwines history and fiction in a fun narrative about the female perspective and self-determination”, describes the festival. The 55th Rotterdam Film Festival will take place from January 29th to February 8th in the Netherlands.

item.title: Music | Mariza in Macau for New Year's concert
item.description: As part of the 2025-2026 concert season, the concert between Portuguese fado singer Mariza and the Macau Orchestra is scheduled for the last day of the year, in the large auditorium of the Macau Cultural Center. Here is a unique opportunity to see, or revisit, one of the great names of Fado, in a mix with classical music Fado singer Mariza will perform in Macau in a concert that marks the arrival of a new year. “Mariza, the Queen of Fado and the Macau Orchestra (OM)” is the name given to this concert that takes place in the large auditorium of the Macau Cultural Center (CCM) on December 31st, starting at 8pm. According to a note from the Cultural Institute (IC), Mariza will perform, “with her deeply emotional voice, a selection of iconic fados, providing the public with a musical experience that transcends genres and spatial and temporal boundaries”. The fado singer is described “as one of the biggest international Fado stars, being recognized for her own musical style, which incorporates elements of soul, jazz and gospel”. "With her powerful voice, she has moved audiences on the most prestigious stages in the world. In this concert, Mariza will present with OM a repertoire that combines traditional and contemporary fado, enriched by the rhythms of Mornas from Cape Verde, 'rhythm and blues' and sounds from Brazil, Spain and Mozambique", being "a celebration of fado with a personal and diverse style". Mariza made her world debut in 1999, having since released several Fado albums, with sales exceeding one million copies worldwide, winning over legions of admirers. She was named Best European World Music Artist three times by BBC Radio 3. The albums “Terra” and “Mundo” earned her nominations for the Latin Grammy Awards, consolidating her status as a global star and her musical influence. The concert will last approximately 1h30 without intermission, and tickets are already on sale, with prices ranging between 180 and 400 patacas. New sounds on the way After releasing “Mariza Canta Amália” in 2020, the artist has dedicated herself to the stage. But last year he released a new single, “Casa”, in 2024, a song from the new album, “Amor”. The fado singer also released the single “Desamor”, which is also part of this album, and in which Mariza collaborates with another musician very different from herself – GSON, from the band Wet Bed Gang, a Portuguese rap group. Quoted by Blitz magazine, during the presentation of “Desamor”, Mariza said that “it would be unlikely that two musicians from completely different backgrounds would meet, but our backgrounds are on the other side of history”. GSON said that “the fact that we are from different poles is what makes the difference in what is being done here”. About the new album, Mariza told the same publication that she was inspired by the various forms of love that exist. “Love of longing, mother's love, family love... love, for me, is not just physical, it goes far beyond that.” Meanwhile, OM announced another musical initiative, planned to take place next year. This is the “Esperança do Futuro” concert, scheduled for May 16th, and whose recruitment program for young local musicians ended on December 12th.

item.title: FRC | Sales of images benefit Tai Po victims
item.description: Another photography exhibition by Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro opened yesterday, on view at the Fundação Rui Cunha (FRC) gallery until January 10th of next year. “What was, will never be again…” is the second volume of a photographic project already released as a book, and which is now getting a new edition. But the highlight is the fact that the proceeds from the sale of this material go to the victims of the fire in the Tai Po area, in Hong Kong. According to a statement, Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro explained that this second volume “continues to be a meeting between the past and the present”, revealing images of places in Macau that have been profoundly transformed by the force of time. "As in the first book, for just over a year I collected old images of the territory, in black and white or sepia, in different formats. I acquired them at auctions, on the Internet, from individuals, in stores and even in Portugal. Some images were also lent to me", said the author, adding that in this last venture, there is a photograph taken in the 19th century, in the Protestant Cemetery. For the photojournalist, “Macau has changed a lot in recent years”, and “old photographs attest to this”. "And now, what to do with them? If, on the one hand, it is still possible to recreate some scenarios, on the other hand, it is impossible to obtain contact points in other photographs, because things simply no longer exist in the territory. It is a difficult job. Everything has changed. Therefore, in the vast majority of cases, what was will never be again...", he further noted. With a preface written by Portuguese writer and professor Henrique Levy, who lived in Macau in the 1980s, the book is designed by Carlos Canhita and endorsed by Ipsis Verbis, with 40 photographs spread over almost 80 pages. The sale price is 250 patacas.

item.title: Docomomo | Documentary by José Maneiras records the architect's career
