item.description: It is simply called “Maneiras” and makes an audiovisual record of a unique work that not only marked a generation of architects but also left its mark on modernism in Macau. The documentary by António Sanmarful, produced by Docomomo in memory of José Maneiras, began to be thought about in 2018 and contains testimonies from him about what he designed Deceased on November 24th, aged 90, José Maneiras, a Macanese architect, did much more than simply design buildings in a small territory full of particularities. He was also a figure with relevant civic participation. But in order to leave an audiovisual record of his work as an architect, Docomomo Macau began thinking and planning, from 2018, the production of a documentary about José Maneiras' legacy, having invited local director António Sanmarful to do it. Maneiras did not live long enough to watch the documentary about himself, presented this Tuesday in the Stanley Ho auditorium, at the Consulate General of Portugal, but he left on record many testimonies about what he projected. To HM, Rui Leão, president of Docomomo Macau, says he has worked closely with António Sanmarful on this project, based on the exhibition dedicated to José Maneiras presented in 2018 at the Lou Lim Ieoc garden. "At that time we did a survey of his works. It was a simple exhibition, in which we intended to show all of this work built in Macau and understand its importance, and we realized that it was little studied. It made sense to leave the record because, in the case of Macau, due to the scale of the city and the lack of critical mass, the study of built works is practically non-existent." Rui Leão has long dedicated himself to studying and looking at the modernist architecture created in Macau, of which José Maneiras was one of the authors. Therefore, he calls the territory “ungrateful”, due to this lack of self-analysis. “People are almost completely unaware of Macau's modernist architecture, and in that sense I think it's a very ungrateful place, because there is no culture that celebrates memory.” Therefore, the importance of making this documentary was imperative, as there is no such “differentiation” between the good and bad things that are being done, as there is no cataloging and analysis. “It was with this perspective, and with a feeling of a certain sadness on the part of the architect Maneiras [that the documentary was made]”, said Rui Leão, adding that “because the work was so damaged, and it was not talked about, we realized that it was important to do something that had a more permanent character”. Some bitterness Graduated from the Porto School of Fine Arts, José Maneiras brought different ways of creating architecture to the territory. "The documentary is based on the filming of some of his works and his testimonies. We realized what an architect, newly arrived in Macau, and with training done in Portugal, saw as important in the works. There was, let's say, a modernist training and things that Maneiras brought [to the practice of architecture] in a very scientific way, and that had to do with the sun exposure [of the buildings]. This was more urgent in Macau, in relation to Portugal, as we are in a subtropical place." One of the first projects was the São Francisco residential building, in front of the Clube Militar, highlighting Rui Leão Maneiras' concern with leaving a free space in conjunction with the historic building in front. "He talks a little about this intervention in the documentary, and that in a way it safeguards the Military Club, by allowing there to be an unbuilt space in front [of the São Francisco building]. This has to do with the civic dimension that it also had, of being concerned about heritage. Then he was called to solve a problem that no one knew how to deal with, which was that confrontation with the Military Club." José Maneiras “took care to rotate the tower so as not to occupy the front of the Military Club, creating a visual opening and a smaller block on the other side, so a small square was created there”, which constitutes “a notable civic concern”, argued Rui Leão. The president of Docomomo also confessed some bitterness with which José Maneiras left, as he saw much of his work already damaged or without proper maintenance. In the case of the São Francisco building, it could be the target of demolition or construction, and “he was quite unhappy with that”. “I don't really know what the situation is like, but I spoke to José Maneiras about the possibility that the lower blocks of this building were about to be demolished, and he was very sad about it”, added Rui Leão. Even so, “there are other buildings of his that have been restored, such as the residences next to the Centro Hospitalar Conde de São Januário”, or the residence for blind people in the Areia Preta area. Design with little José Maneiras began to project in Macau during the years of Portuguese administration, when the Estado Novo regime was in force in Portugal and the territory was subject, like the remaining overseas territories, to Development Plans for budgetary issues. Money was, therefore, little and controlled. “In the documentary he also talks about things that were important at the time, such as starting to build at height, which was new, and also the construction economy, because in the 50s and 60s there wasn't much money and there was a much greater need to make this construction economy.” José Maneiras belonged to the list of Macanese architects who left their mark, such as Canavarro Nolasco da Silva and Aureliano Guterres Jorge, despite their basic training being in engineering; or even José Lei. "They were people integrated into society in a completely different way [in relation to those who came from outside], and who understood the issues, being closer to the client, sharing the world and ways of creating. I'm not saying that, theoretically, the architecture of one and the other was stylistically different, but I'm talking about the fact that they made proposals and asked different questions", concluded Rui Leão.

item.title: Commerce | Mannings closes all stores in the Interior
item.description: On Tuesday, the Mannings Group announced the closure of all physical stores in the Interior as well as the online store and electronic platforms Tmall, JD and Pinduoduo. The closure of physical stores will take place on January 15th. In the case of online stores, the deactivation will take place next week. The closures were explained with the need to adjust the commercial strategy. Despite these closures, customers in the Interior will be able to continue purchasing products through the group's Hong Kong portal. According to company data, Mannings has more than 320 stores in Hong Kong and Macau. Since 2004, the group entered the Interior market, and the number of stores reached 200 units, during the period with the highest demand. Currently, the number of stores is 120 units.

item.title: Housing | Fewer transactions and cheaper homes
item.description: The housing market continues to decline consistently. In annual terms, November saw a 20.4 percent reduction in the number of transactions and a 10.9 percent reduction in the average price per square meter In November, the number of housing transactions showed an annual reduction of 20.4 percent, according to the most recent data published by the Directorate of Financial Services (DSF). Last month, 238 transactions were registered, compared to 299 transactions in November 2024, a reduction of 61 transactions. The most active market in November this year was the Macau Peninsula with 173 transactions, 35 fewer than last year, which represented a drop of 16.8 percent. In Taipa, 44 housing sales were registered, 24 fewer than last year, when 68 were registered. Finally, in Coloane, 21 transactions were registered, a reduction of two sales compared to the same period last year. In terms of housing prices, the month of November was marked by a reduction in the square meter, compared to the same month in 2024, from 74,364 patacas to 69,311 patacas. This represented an annual difference of 5,053 patacas or 6.8 percent. The price reduction was common to all three markets. In Coloane, the average price per square meter fell from 93,970 patacas to 83,707 patacas, a difference of 10.9 percent. In the Peninsula and Taipa prices also showed a negative trend. In Macau, the square meter depreciated in the space of one year from 70,526 patacas to 66,303 patacas, a difference of 6.0 percent. In Taipa, the reduction was from 78,144 patacas to 71,155 patacas, an annual devaluation of 8.9 percent. Double negative The monthly comparison also shows a market shrinking in terms of the number of transactions and prices charged. Between October and November this year, the average price per square meter decreased by 4.9 percent, from 72,873 patacas per square meter to 69,311 patacas per square meter. The price reduction was due to the Peninsula market, with a decrease from 72,629 patacas to 66,303 patacas, corresponding to 8.7 percent, and Coloane, with a reduction in prices from 87,535 patacas to 83,707 patacas, corresponding to 4.4 percent. In Taipa, the square meter appreciated by 11.5 percent in the space of one month from 63,802 patacas to 71,155 patacas, contrary to the general trend.

item.title: Macau Initiative | Manifesto defends investment in technology
item.description: The International Forum for Civilizational Exchange ended yesterday with the release of the 'Macau Initiative' of a manifesto that calls on young people to take advantage of technology in the service of dialogue and cooperation between civilizations. At the closing ceremony, the president of the Macau Cultural Institute, which organized the forum, read the document, which “encourages young people to take advantage of new technologies, such as digitalization and smart applications”. Leong Wai Man stated that it is necessary to train new generations “so that they become heirs and innovators of mutual learning between civilizations” and build a world that is “inclusive, cooperative and forward-looking”. The manifesto also defends the need to not only protect the shared heritage of humanity, but also to reinforce “the innovative use of the various forms of tangible and intangible cultural heritage”. The document calls for “deep exploration of the contemporary value of the historical cultures of all countries”, using “creative transformation” to apply “traditional wisdom” in the modern world. Macau is the ideal place for this initiative, says the manifesto, due to the “valuable experience of harmonious coexistence of civilizations reflected in the historic center” of the region. The forum also marked 20 years since the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) classified the historic center of Macau as a World Heritage Site in 2005.

item.title: SJM | Green light for the acquisition of L’Arc casino
item.description: The Government yesterday approved the deal that will “save” the only satellite casino in the territory, giving the green light to the acquisition of Royal Arc by SJM Resorts. The approval, which comes two days after the group's shareholders voted in favor, required opinions from several public services It's official. The L’Arc casino is part of the portfolio of properties operated by the gaming concessionaire SJM Resorts. The Government gave the green light to the deal yesterday through an order from the Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam Vai Man, published in the Official Bulletin. The approval allows gaming to operate, beyond December 31, 2025, at the only satellite casino in the territory to survive the changes that regulate the casino industry. Therefore, the order from the Secretary for Transport and Public Works indicates that “the transfer of the concession was authorized, in accordance with what was proposed in the opinion of the Land Commission”, after the request to transfer the fraction where the casino and hotel is located was presented on November 11th. In the request, SJM claimed that the “transmission aims to maintain the continuous exploration and operation of the casino existing in that autonomous fraction, which operates as a satellite casino, transforming it into a casino belonging to the gaming concessionaire”. In addition to the positive opinion of the Land Commission, after a meeting on December 4th, the transfer received approval from several public services. “After gathering the opinions of the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Directorate and the Tourism Services Directorate, the request was assessed by the Land and Urban Construction Services Directorate, which ruled in favor as there were no outstanding prizes, fees, rents, fees or taxes relating to the concession and there was no evidence that the transfer was requested for speculative purposes”, is stated in the order from Raymond Tam Vai Man. Step by step The building where the casino is located has “62 floors, including two refuge floors, two mezzanine floors and three basement floors, intended for housing, commerce, a 5-star hotel, residential parking and hotel parking”. It is recalled that SJM Holdings held an extraordinary general meeting on Monday where shareholders voted overwhelmingly in favor of the acquisition of the former satellite casino L’Arc, according to a note sent by the group to the Hong Kong stock exchange. The acquisition, approved by 99.93 percent, will cost HK$1.75 billion. Nine of Macau's 11 “satellite casinos” have already closed. The last to close its doors, on December 9th, was Fortuna, with more than 550 employees. The tenth, Landmark, which has 1,169 workers, will close on December 30th. SJM highlighted that all employees of the 'satellite casinos' with resident status in Macau and directly hired by the company have guaranteed employment in other casinos in the group. As for other local workers, “they are invited to apply for related vacancies” within the group, “with priority for hiring” and with conditions equal to those they had.

item.title: Football | Sporting wants to support Hengqin in training
item.description: The Lisbon club's intention was expressed after a visit to Europe by the Executive Committee of the Deep Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau in Hengqin Sporting Clube de Portugal showed interest in collaborating with Hengqin, next to Macau, in training young footballers, said authorities in the Chinese special economic zone. According to a statement released on Monday night, a delegation from the Executive Committee of the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin was in Europe at the beginning of the month. In Portugal, the delegation visited Sporting Clube de Portugal, described as “a powerhouse of European football”, and “investigated the youth training system” of the Cristiano Ronaldo Academy. According to the statement, the Portuguese club “expressed its availability to introduce a high-level youth football training system” on Ilha da Montanha. In April, the Macau Government said it wants to hire a European team to provide football training to younger people, in a bid to develop this sport in the territory. “This year, we are going to try to expand football training for young people, we are going to try to hire a team from Europe to train young people”, said the then president of the region's Sports Institute, in the Legislative Assembly. Without providing details about this European team, Luís Gomes also said that other football events are about to be launched: “young people from cities in the Greater Bay Area will be invited to play” in Macau and a “Hengqin-Macau cup will be created to promote sport among young people”. A lot to recover The Macau men's team, made up of amateur players, is currently ranked 193rd in the FIFA world rankings, made up of 210 teams. Among Portuguese-speaking countries or regions, only Timor-Leste is behind Macau, in 198th. The Macau football team has not won a game since June 2019, at the time as part of qualifying for the 2022 World Cup. The local team beat Sri Lanka 1-0, in the first qualifying leg. However, the association withdrew from the second game, because the directors were afraid to visit Sri Lanka, following the occurrence of terrorist attacks. Since then the team has played 12 games, with 11 defeats and one draw. In March, deputy Eddie Wu Chou Kit defended cooperation with the Portuguese Professional Football League (LPFP) to organize friendly games with “top European teams” in Macau. In an intervention in parliament, Eddie Wu proposed “establishing [a] deep cooperation” with the LPFP to create, “together, a permanent training base”. The deputy explained that the objective would be “to attract top teams from Europe to train and hold traveling games, promoting sporting and cultural exchange at an international level”.

item.title: Economic Association | Expected GDP growth of 5.4%
item.description: Macau's annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth for 2025 is expected to reach 5.4 percent compared to the previous year, according to a report published on Monday by the Macau Economic Association. The local association's forecast is 0.8 percentage points above Fitch Ratings' projection, which revised downwards its estimates of GDP growth from 6.9 percent this year, to 4.6 percent. Regarding next year, the association's report points to “numerous uncertainties and unpredictable elements in the world economy”. However, Macau's economy will remain “stable” and with good growth prospects, thanks to macroeconomic factors such as the recovery in Mainland China and the efforts of the Government and the tourism industry to boost regional and international tourism markets. The economic prosperity index over the next three months is also expected to remain stable, according to the estimate, with a slight increase between January and February.

item.title: SJM | Acquisition of L’Arc casino approved
item.description: Gaming concessionaire SJM Holdings held an extraordinary general meeting on Monday where shareholders voted overwhelmingly in favor of the acquisition of the former satellite casino L'Arc, according to a note sent by the group to the Hong Kong stock exchange. The acquisition, approved by 99.93 percent, will cost HK$1.75 billion. Shareholders also approved a loan agreement from the group to Angela Leong worth 177.3 million Hong Kong dollars. At the time of announcing the acquisition and closure of the Ponte 16 casino, Daisy Ho stated that “Hotel L’Arc is centrally located within an active cluster of gaming, hospitality and tourist traffic on the Macau Peninsula which, combined with the surrounding tourist attractions, creates opportunities that few places can match.”

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the measure of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technology and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and imposing, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Ambos os poetas assanhados por uma certa ideia de santidade, foi-lhes idêntica a inabilidade de romper o cerco da pele com o transbordo em dique alheio, a mesma maldição de sublimar a concreta ferocidade de eros com a mansuetude dos versos. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the position of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, deferred, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will indeed be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: Macron calls for rebalancing relations with China
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron defended an urgent rebalance in economic relations between the European Union (EU) and China, warning that, without progress, Brussels could be forced to adopt more protectionist measures. In an opinion article published yesterday in the British newspaper Financial Times, Macron highlights that China's trade surplus with the rest of the world has already reached one billion dollars, and that the imbalance with the EU has doubled in the last decade, reaching 300 billion euros. “This situation is not sustainable, neither for Europe nor for China”, he observes. The French head of state recognizes that the current wave of Chinese exports to the European market is partly due to tariffs imposed by the United States and weak domestic consumption in China. However, it states that “responding with tariffs and quotas would be a non-cooperative solution”. Macron rather calls for a coordinated approach that involves three fronts: strengthening European competitiveness, mobilizing savings for domestic investment and encouraging structural reforms in the Chinese economy. “Europe’s first step must be to implement a new economic agenda based on competitiveness, innovation and protection”, he argues. Macron defended Europe's right to adopt a “European preference” to support strategic sectors such as automobiles, energy, health and technology, as long as they comply with international rules. “Protecting against unfair competition is the basis of resilience”, he maintains. As for financing this transformation, the French President proposes channeling part of the approximately 30 billion euros in savings accumulated in the EU – of which 300 billion are invested annually abroad – to European companies. “It’s time for us Europeans to take the risk of investing in our own companies”, he argues. Eyes on China Macron emphasizes, however, that China also has responsibilities. “Beijing needs to correct its internal imbalances”, he states, defending a fiscal policy that is more favorable to consumption and the transition to a service economy. The French President also calls for a rebalance in foreign direct investment (FDI) flows, recalling that the EU invested around 240 billion euros in China, while Chinese investment in Europe was below 65 billion. “Europe must remain open to Chinese investment in sectors where China leads, as long as this contributes to employment, innovation and technological sharing”, he writes. Macron reiterates his call for a framework of economic cooperation between the EU, China and the US, warning that, in the absence of progress, Europe will have to resort to “firmer measures”. "I prefer cooperation. But, if necessary, I will defend the use of protectionist measures", he warns, adding that the French presidency of the G7, next year, will put the rebalancing of global asymmetries at the top of the agenda. “I believe that, if we truly take into account the needs and interests of each person, we can build an international macroeconomic agenda that benefits everyone”, he states.

item.title: Japan | Chinese tourism in Japan slows down in November
item.description: The arrival of Chinese tourists to Japan slowed down in November, amid diplomatic tension between Tokyo and Beijing, despite the archipelago having registered a record number of foreign visitors, according to official data released yesterday. The total number of international tourist arrivals in November was 3,518,000, an increase of 10.4 percent compared to the same month in 2024, indicated the Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO). Among the visitors, 562 thousand came from mainland China – a year-on-year increase of 3 percent, but well below previous months. In October, Japan had received 715 thousand Chinese tourists and, in September, 775 thousand – growth of close to 20 percent year-on-year. “In addition to the demand for travel to Japan slowing down at this time of year, the Chinese Government warned the population to avoid traveling to the country”, said JNTO, highlighting that the year-on-year increase was also due to the greater supply of seats on flights. The slowdown coincided with the recommendation issued by Chinese authorities following statements by Japanese Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, about Taiwan, which reignited diplomatic tensions between the two countries. Even so, between January and November, China remained the main source of tourists to Japan, with 8.7 million visitors, followed by South Korea (8.4 million). In the first eleven months of 2025, Japan received 39,065,600 international visitors – 17 percent more than in the same period of the previous year –, already surpassing the record of 36.87 million registered in 2024 and approaching the target of 40 million by the end of this year. The continued growth of tourism has fueled a national debate about the impacts of mass tourism, with some conservative parties demanding new restrictions on the entry of foreigners and stricter rules to preserve coexistence in local communities.

item.title: Deaths in the ongoing clash between Thailand and Cambodia already exceed those in July
item.description: The armed conflict between Thailand and Cambodia in the border region left at least 52 people dead, a number that exceeded the number of victims of the July clashes, which killed 50 people, according to a report updated yesterday. Thailand's Internal Security Operations Command raised the number of Thai soldiers killed to 19 and kept the number of civilian deaths at 16. Cambodian Defense Ministry spokeswoman Maly Socheata counted 17 civilian deaths, including a child. The conflict arises from an old dispute between the two countries over the sovereignty of territories close to the common border, which extends for approximately 820 kilometers and was mapped by France in 1907, when Cambodia was part of French Indochina. Phnom Penh said yesterday that Thai forces had “intensified attacks” at certain points along the border in recent hours and emphasized that they had carried out new bombings with F-16 fighter jets. In addition to the armed conflict, the two neighboring countries are fighting a war of numbers: Cambodia avoids releasing information about soldier deaths, while Thai authorities claim that there are more than 500 casualties on the opposing side. Last week, Cambodian authorities dismissed reports of soldier deaths reported by Thailand. The Thai Ministry of Defense, in turn, alluded to an “information war” also underway, local media reported yesterday. Donald to the noise The new wave of crossfire, which both sides accuse each other of having started, broke out on December 7th, with the 11 days of conflict already surpassing by almost a week the five days of violence in July, which ended after the mediation of several countries, led by Malaysia and including the United States. North American President Donald Trump boasts of having put an end – albeit temporarily – to hostilities between the two countries in an agreement signed on October 26, and intervened again in the conflict, without apparent success, after its resurgence. “[Trump] should ask Cambodia to stop firing first at Thailand, because Thailand has never fired first,” said Thai Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul, according to local media, after a telephone conversation with the American leader last week.

item.title: Ukraine | China criticizes possible use of frozen Russian assets in the EU
item.description: China yesterday expressed its “opposition to illegal unilateral sanctions not authorized by the United Nations Security Council”, given the possibility of the European Union using revenue from frozen Russian assets to help Ukraine. “These types of sanctions violate international law,” said Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Guo Jiakun during a press conference in Beijing. Guo also called for the creation of “a positive environment and favorable conditions to promote peace talks”, stressing that “conditions conducive to a political solution to the crisis in Ukraine must be created, and not the other way around”. China's position comes on the eve of the summit of the leaders of the 27 EU member states, which will discuss, among other options, the possibility of investing Russian assets frozen in European territory as collateral for a new loan to Ukraine, if Moscow refuses to pay for the damage caused by the war. The measure has generated divisions, with countries such as Belgium, Italy or Bulgaria expressing reservations. Since the start of the large-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, China has maintained an ambiguous stance, calling simultaneously for respect for the territorial integrity of all countries, including Ukraine, and consideration of the “legitimate security concerns” of all parties – an implicit reference to Russia. Beijing has been strengthening its alliance with Moscow and rejected accusations by Western countries that it provides military support to Russia, insisting that these are unfounded allegations.

item.title: Justice | 27 people convicted of trafficking in strategic minerals
item.description: A Chinese court yesterday sentenced 27 people to sentences of up to 12 years in prison for smuggling antimony ingots, in a case that arises in a context of tightening Chinese controls on exports of strategic minerals. According to a statement released on the social network WeChat, the Shenzhen Intermediate People's Court imposed a twelve-year prison sentence and a fine of one million yuan on the main defendant, identified as Wang Wubin. According to the sentence, Wang collaborated with an international network of smugglers and, between February and March of this year, recruited several people to acquire antimony ingots, which were then exported illegally, without the licenses required by the Chinese authorities. China is the world's largest producer of antimony – a metal used in industrial alloys and semiconductors – and included the element on its list of exports subject to control in September last year. Like gallium and germanium, antimony was temporarily banned from being sold to the United States, in response to the trade war between the two countries. The remaining 26 defendants, most of whom were recruited by Wang to purchase and transport the metal, were sentenced to sentences ranging from four months to five years in prison, depending on the quantity trafficked. The case involves the smuggling of more than 166 metric tons of antimony, of which around 96 tons were seized by Chinese customs authorities, the court said.

item.title: HK | Drugs seized in the hull of a ship coming from Brazil
item.description: More than 400 kilos of cocaine, hidden in the hull of a Brazilian ship, were seized by authorities in the neighboring region. The case is the first of its kind, with the value of the drug amounting to approximately 2t56 million Hong Kong dollars Hong Kong police announced the first case of drug trafficking in the hull of a long-haul ship, a vessel coming from Brazil. Customs officials in the Chinese region seized around 417 kilograms of cocaine, with an estimated market value of 256 million Hong Kong dollars. According to a statement released on Tuesday, the operation was carried out in conjunction with the anti-smuggling department of Mainland China Customs. “Through an intelligence analysis and a risk assessment”, the Hong Kong police suspected that criminals were using the underwater structure of a 333 meter long and 48 meter wide ship, which departed from Brazil, to hide drugs. In an inspection carried out on November 5, at the Tsing Yi container terminal, Hong Kong Customs found 11 bags in a compartment of the boat, each containing between five and ten kilos of cocaine. Later, after an investigation, police officers arrested two men, aged 45 and 37, suspected of being involved in this drug trafficking case, who have since been released. The investigation is ongoing and the possibility of further arrests is not ruled out, Hong Kong Customs highlighted. At a press conference also held on Tuesday, the head of the Customs Drug Investigation Department said that the drug was discovered with the help of underwater robots. Distribution warehouse According to local press, Lau Yuk-lung revealed that the cocaine was hidden in a compartment located at a depth of 11 meters below sea level. “Hiding drugs under a vessel is extremely rare”, highlighted the officer, especially because the compartment has “a very narrow entrance”. “We do not rule out the possibility that only professional divers will be able to access the site, as no ordinary person would be able to enter,” said Lau. “The criminal group hid the drugs in the compartment and thought it was a relatively safe place,” added the officer. Customs believes that the criminal group intended to use the ship as a mobile drug depot at sea, which could distribute the cocaine to different regions. In 2022, Hong Kong police seized 16.5 kilograms of cocaine in containers coming from Brazil, with a street value of 14 million Hong Kong dollars. Customs officials in the region found the drug, hidden in two of the 230 bales of cotton fibers coming from Brazil, and later detained three suspects. The crime of drug trafficking is punishable in the Chinese region with a fine of up to five million Hong Kong dollars and a prison sentence that can be life.

item.title: Brazil | CMOC buys four gold mines in Portugal for 863 million euros
item.description: Chinese mining giant CMOC will acquire the operations of Canadian Equinox in Brazil for 863 million euros, gaining exploration rights over four gold mines, including reserves in Maranhão, Bahia and Minas Gerais. In a statement published on its official portal, the Chinese company indicates that it expects to complete the operation in the first quarter of 2026, still subject to approval from the competent regulators. The sale will be completed through an initial payment of 900 million dollars and an additional payment of 115 million dollars, subject to sales volume during the first year after the official conclusion of the deal. CMOC will have three explorations that total around 3.87 million ounces of gold in reserves: Aurizona, in the state of Maranhão (northeast of Brazil); the Bahia complex (east), which includes the Fazenda and Santa Luz mines; and RDM, in the state of Minas Gerais (center). “Taking into account Brazil’s rich natural resources and stable geopolitical environment, this acquisition represents a strategic addition to our existing assets, creating a stronger synergy and a growing presence for CMOC in South America,” said company president Liu Jianfeng. The company says that, with this purchase and the start of operations at the Odin mine (Ecuador), its gold production could exceed 20 tons per year. According to the economic information newspaper Securities Times, these levels would place CMOC among the main gold producers in China, although still behind the sector leaders, Zijin Mining and Shandong Gold. The newspaper recalls that CMOC is currently the world's largest producer of cobalt and is among the ten largest copper producers. Gold, considered a safe haven asset in periods of uncertainty, has fluctuated in recent days. Experts anticipate the metal will continue to rise into 2026, driven by central bank purchases.

item.title: Thailand wants Cambodia to be the first to enter into a truce
item.description: Thailand declared yesterday that Cambodia must assume a ceasefire between them, in a border conflict that has already left at least 32 dead in 10 days and around 800,000 displaced. “Cambodia must announce the ceasefire first, as it is the aggressor on Thai territory,” said Thai Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maratee Nalita Andamo at a press conference. That government official stressed that, “secondly, the ceasefire must be implemented and must be maintained”. “Thirdly, Cambodia must sincerely cooperate with demining efforts (in border areas),” he added. According to the latest official figures, 17 people were killed on the Thai side (16 soldiers and one civilian) and 15 on the Cambodian side, all civilians. Cambodia on Monday accused Thailand of bombing Siem Reap province, where the famous Angkor temples are located, for the first time since border clashes resumed on December 7. “The Thai army expanded the scope of its violent attack, using an F-16 fighter to drop two bombs near a camp for displaced civilians in the Srei Snam district,” the Cambodian Ministry of Defense said in a statement. Thailand confirmed that fighting continued yesterday in the border regions, without mentioning, however, the province of Siem Reap. The Srei Snam district is about 70 kilometers from the disputed border and less than an hour and a half drive from the Angkor Wat complex, a jewel of Khmer architecture and Cambodia's main tourist attraction. Pointed fingers The two countries accuse each other of having unleashed hostilities, which led to the evacuation of around 800,000 people from both sides of the border. A first episode of violence caused 43 deaths in July, before a truce and the signing of a ceasefire agreement in October, which saw the intervention of the President of the United States of America, Donald Trump. Trump said on Friday that the leaders of Thailand and Cambodia had agreed to a truce after a phone call, but the Thai government denied this and fighting continued over the weekend.

item.title: Commerce | Taxes up to 19.8% on European pork
item.description: Chinese authorities have announced new duties on European pork imports to be applied over the next five years. The values, which vary between 4.9 percent and 19.8 percent, are significantly lower than those currently in force China's Ministry of Commerce announced yesterday that it will apply tariffs of up to 19.8 percent on pork imports from the European Union, following an investigation into alleged unfair competition that began in 2024. However, the new rates, which come into force today and will last for five years, are significantly lower than the provisional tariffs of up to 62.4 percent applied since September to the European pork sector. According to the statement published on the ministry's official portal, the rates will vary between 4.9 percent – ​​applied exclusively to the Spanish company Litera Meat, included as a sample in the investigation – and 19.8 percent, which will apply to companies that did not cooperate in the process, as well as the producer Vion, from the Netherlands. For companies that collaborated with the investigation, the final rate will be 9.8 percent. The investigation was launched in 2023 and extended in June this year, with the Chinese authorities justifying the extension of the deadline with the “complexity” of the case. The case covered chilled or frozen pork, offal and fat, and sought to determine whether European exports violated competition rules and harmed local industry. Spain was one of the most targeted countries, as it is the largest European supplier of pork to China, especially pork remains that are in low demand on the European market, such as ears, snouts or feet, but are highly valued on the Chinese market. In 2024, Spain exported around 540 thousand tons of pork products to China, worth 1,097 million euros, which represented almost 20 percent of the total volume and 12.5 percent of the value of the sector's exports, according to data from the Interporc association. Other investigations The investigation into the pig sector is part of a broader package of trade measures adopted by Beijing in retaliation against the 'anti-dumping' duties imposed by the European Commission, in October 2024, on electric vehicles manufactured in China - in a vote in which Spain abstained. Since then, Chinese authorities have also opened anti-dumping investigations into other European products, such as brandy and dairy products. These measures worsened tensions between China and Brussels, in a context already marked by trade disputes, restrictions on the access of European companies to the Chinese market, controls on rare earth exports and friction in supply chains. The practice of ‘dumping’ consists of selling products on a foreign market at a price lower than the cost of production. The practice is made possible by the granting of subsidies.

item.title: Christian Montag, UM Institute for Collaborative Innovation: “AI cannot imitate the human touch”
item.description: Can artificial intelligence help combat loneliness? The issue was analyzed in a study by the University of Macau, led by academic Christian Montag. The director of the Institute for Collaborative Innovation emphasizes that AI tools “are not long-term solutions” on a psychological level How can artificial intelligence (AI) help overcome feelings of loneliness, if social networks cannot achieve this goal? The “needs and gratifications theory” states that technology can only be successful if its use satisfies human needs, such as, for example, the need for social interaction. With AI companions, whether as stand-alone products or integrated into social media platforms, we have reached a new level, because human beings start talking to an artificial person and not with another human person, as happens on social media. Specific problems arise with these new AI companions, in that there are overly pleasant and charming AI systems that do not challenge a person's biased views of the world. Furthermore, many people around the world have become excessively dependent on these products, using them without critical reflection. One of the conclusions of your study is that AI cannot, on its own, resolve feelings of loneliness. What steps in the investigation were followed to reach this conclusion? There are well-conducted studies that show that interactions with AI companions can actually reduce feelings of loneliness. We do not doubt these results nor deny the potential that can arise from these interactions between humans and AI, as long as such systems are designed safely and when a human is not available. That said, we believe that these interactions between humans and AI do not represent a long-term solution. Why? This is due to the absence of social contact and the real presence of another human being when turning to AI companions based on large-scale language models, especially in moments of desperation. We have reviewed a vast literature that demonstrates that we need to take our evolutionary heritage seriously, with the real need for other human beings, particularly in the age of AI. Our perspective is based on many years of research in the area of ​​affective neuroscience. Still, it is clearly necessary to develop more new empirical studies that directly address interactions with AI and support this vision. We run the risk of AI causing profound cognitive changes in people. To what extent? Can we change as human beings, especially when it comes to our need for others? The same discussion arose with the appearance of smartphones. It is important to note that this oldest discussion has not yet been resolved: what happens or happened to our cognitive abilities when we began to permanently outsource the learning of telephone numbers, the guidance from A to B, among other tasks, to a machine? Recent research from MIT [Massachusetts Institute of Technology] suggests that the brain is less activated when using ChatGPT for writing tasks, compared to writing without such support. To me, this is not surprising and should not lead to moral panics. We have other more urgent problems, such as when real difficulties arise when inequalities in society increase, this is because some people use AI and others do not invest in this area. What are the concrete impacts? Some people may soon become very, very productive, while those who are not educated to use AI properly will not be able to keep up. Interestingly, we have observed in recent research that people with a deep learning style are more willing to engage with AI to become more productive. As for the question of whether we have changed in relation to our need for others, I highly doubt that, as these evolutionary impulses are genetically anchored in our species and we cannot simply eliminate them. Social needs are an essential part of what it means to be human. Could these cognitive changes, if they occur, be more significant in young people than in adults, for example? Interesting question. We know, from some studies on attitudes towards AI, that younger users tend to have more positive views about AI and, therefore, are more likely to adopt it in their daily lives. However, we are currently observing something quite problematic, such as the fact that AI is often eliminating jobs for young people just leaving university. Thus, AI appears to make it more difficult to enter the job market after obtaining a university degree. In other words, a lack of work experience makes things difficult for many young people. In the end, this could also lead to young people's perception of AI becoming more negative soon. How should governments legislate or adopt policies to promote healthy acceptance and use of AI in society and schools? We see very different approaches around the world to responding to the AI ​​revolution. I am German and, in Europe, we are seeing strong regulatory efforts with the so-called Artificial Intelligence Regulation (Artificial Intelligence Act). Personally, I am not convinced that the current European regulatory scheme is well planned, as I think it is too strict and, in some points, uses legally undefined terms, although I applaud the aim of promoting reliable AI and trying to reduce harm. I think the current regulation of AI in the European Union could go too far and end up harming the European economy by stifling much-needed innovation. But there are real dangers associated with AI and some regulation is needed. What dangers? I'm talking, for example, about the unregulated fusion between biotechnology and AI that could result in harm if people start to “create” new viruses in their backyards. I find Singapore's approach based on lifelong learning as a response to the AI ​​revolution very interesting. The Singapore Government offers its citizens the possibility of obtaining an academic degree in AI from the age of 40, with financial support from the State itself. What I like about this approach is that we need to remind people that it is also their responsibility to acquire new skills throughout their lives. This mentality must be instilled from an early age in schools. In what areas of our lives can large-scale language models (LLMs) do more good than harm? There are many routine and repetitive tasks where AI will be really useful to humans. However, we know from scientific literature that humans experience what is called “algorithm aversion”: in some areas of our lives, people do not like AI playing a role. For example, when we talk about couples therapy, people clearly prefer to talk to a human being than an AI system. Perhaps the closer we come to our evolutionary heritage in terms of caring for each other, the more the role of AI must be carefully monitored and reflected upon if we want it to have a place there. Personally, I wouldn't want to see my child being taken care of in kindergarten by an AI-powered robot. How should psychology adapt to AI, given the growing number of people using it for this purpose? There are different perspectives on this topic. Firstly, not everyone knows that psychology is a discipline that relies heavily on data. Therefore, psychology students are trained to become excellent data scientists. In this context, it is logical that our discipline adopts AI as a data analysis tool. However, I think it speaks to how psychologists view the increasing use of AI in human relationships. As with many things, this is complex. If AI enables better human communication, such as improving hearing aids for people with hearing problems, that is very welcome. If AI replaces human relationships, from my perspective it will cause problems. As we exposed in our most recent work, AI cannot currently successfully imitate human social touch or the real presence of another person. At the Center for Cognitive and Brain Science at the University of Macau, what are the main projects developed in this area? We have unique research opportunities at the University of Macau to study interactions between humans and AI, using neuroscientific techniques. I hope we can publish very interesting discoveries in the near future. Humanity still lives here Recently published in the scientific journal “Trends and Cognitive Sciences”, the article “Can AI really help solve the loneliness epidemic?” [Can AI Really Help Solve the Loneliness Epidemic?] counts Christian Montag, associate director of the Institute for Collaborative Innovation at the University of Macau (UM) as lead author, followed by academics Michiel Spapé, associate professor at the Center for Cognitive and Brain Sciences at UM, and Benjamin Becker, professor at the Department of Psychology at the University of Hong Kong, as co-authors. According to a press release released by UM regarding this investigation, one of the main conclusions is that AI “will probably not be a long-term solution to human loneliness”. Quoted in this note, Christian Montag stated that “if a person is lonely, they long for the physical presence of someone close to them”, and this “is very difficult to imitate with the available chatbots”. "The major language models operate primarily through text communication. Clearly, this is not enough to provide lonely people with the best cure for loneliness: direct in-person support," he stated. According to the World Health Organization, “loneliness affects one in six people worldwide”, having been “identified as a global public health concern”. Despite the sign, the study points to a positive side of this universe, noting that “AI technology has significant potential to support human beings in moments of psychological crisis, especially when human intervention is not available”. However, “the researchers argue that the technology must be made safer before it can be used in this context”, emphasizing “the importance of remembering our evolutionary heritage and the need for genuine interpersonal connections”.

item.title: Luís Bernardino, academic: “We need to define a defense cooperation strategy” for the CPLP
item.description: The book “25 Years of Defense Cooperation at CPLP” was released in 2023 in digital format and, two years later, reached the printed version. Luís Bernardino, co-author linked to the Autonomous University of Lisbon, highlights positive developments since the creation of the Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, despite inaction and controversies with Equatorial Guinea “25 Years of Defense Cooperation in the CPLP [Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries]” was released as an e-book and is now available in print. Why edit this book? This book talks about the 25 years of cooperation in the CPLP defense area and is written by me, together with a colleague from Brazil, Camila Rizzi. It results from a research project developed at the CPLP Strategic Analysis Center, based in Mozambique. It has the CPLP defense component and makes strategic reflection on this topic. Due to the fact that 25 years of cooperation have passed in this area, we wanted to carry out an evaluation and the book so that it would remain in the history of the organization. In 2023, there were no financial conditions to publish the book on paper as we wanted, and it was now launched on November 18th, in Maputo. There is criticism regarding the effective action of the CPLP. Do you consider that this organism has grown sustainably? The assessment I make is in the area of ​​defense. When the CPLP was created, cooperation in the area of ​​defense was not included in the initial six areas. This area only emerged in 1998. The CPLP was born with six main areas – culture, language, political-diplomatic concentration – and currently has 26 areas of cooperation, which is proof that it has grown in a sustained manner. Obviously, with ups and downs, situations have become easier over these almost 30 years. But what stands out in this book, in the area of ​​defense, is that there was a very consolidated and participated growth. In these 25 years, a lot of interesting things have been done and the evaluation is positive. And the future? We need to define a defense cooperation strategy and what we want for the CPLP in this area over the next 25 years. This is the challenge we face, of greater activity and initiative, so that cooperation and defense can be strategic in what is cooperation within States. So that it can be more visible and effectively allow for growth, participation and development, or even greater commitment, in regional contexts. But looking at the past, present and future, what has the dynamic been like in the defense area? The book shows a certain dynamic of substantial constitutional growth in the first phase. Then there were very interesting developments, with some protocols and cooperation at the level of the Armed Forces, but there is still a lot to do, namely looking at the area of ​​defense cooperation as a strategic area. The global geopolitical system appears to be changing very quickly, following a multipolar path. Should the CPLP have another role in this context, with actors such as China, Russia or the United States? The CPLP is not a multilateral instrument, it is not an organization of that level. We have to place the CPLP at the level of the Commonwealth, for example, of organizations at a cultural, linguistic level, of partnership between countries, of concern for development. What I usually say is that the CPLP is a good diplomatic communication instrument, a soft power in areas related to conflict management and prevention. Let us not expect there to be armed forces, or an army, from the CPLP. This body is one of dialogue and cooperation. What we do, in terms of defense, is exactly that, create partnerships so that there are mechanisms for responding to disasters, to provide training capacity for the armed forces. There are even those who ask the question: why did the CPLP not intervene in Cabo Delgado, in Mozambique, on the issue of terrorism? And why? Because the CPLP is not a hard power mechanism, it has no capacity, doctrine, logistics, mandate or viability to be used in combat operations. And CPLP Member States are very aware that we are a very good mechanism for cooperation, partnership and development, with contributions to culture and language. Therefore, the CPLP will not intervene in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, because that is not its area, nor does it have mechanisms for this dynamic. Is the existence of the CPLP justified? I think so, obviously, because, as I said, the CPLP is a very good instrument in terms of cooperation, the dissemination of the Portuguese language, of history. The fact is that we have around 350 million people who speak Portuguese. We have 30 countries that are associated observers, such as Ukraine, Chile, and Portuguese culture is represented in this organization. Each country has what it wants from the CPLP and gives it the importance it thinks it should give, and this depends on the foreign policy of each State. But I think the CPLP makes a lot of sense in the world we live in, and does so as a multilateral representative of language, culture, cooperation between Portuguese-speaking states, and those that ultimately have some affinity [with the Portuguese-speaking world]. The Macau issue is very specific to this organization. Macau has the role of a commercial platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries, and China has an agenda for Lusophony. Before 1999 Macau had its own status within the CPLP, as it was administered by Portuguese. There was a Joint Declaration that allowed Macau, not being a Member State, to have, in a certain way, a protocol [with the CPLP]. When it became a Macao SAR, things changed and it lost that connection status, and Macau is not a member of the CPLP, and obviously cannot be. Neither does China, and it cannot be. Therefore, there is an associated observer status here that arises for countries, international and regional organizations, and even territorial entities with their own administration, which is also not quite the case in Macau. The territory is in limbo, between having a very strong history linked to Lusofonia, and having an administration very linked to China, which gives it, in my perspective, two dynamics. In what sense? Macau is a fundamental element in the connection between the CPLP countries and China. For all reasons, but due to the issue of language, history, and its representation, it is a fundamental actor in this cooperation. Macau must effectively be seen as a partner and as a gateway for China to Portuguese-speaking countries. This is what, in a way, is already happening, and this is what the CPLP will be paying attention to, in this relationship in which Macau has a special status. Whether we like it or not, it has an impact. Macau is an attractive factor in facilitating relations between China and Angola, Portugal or Brazil. Does Equatorial Guinea's stay in the CPLP raise questions of credibility? I agree with you. In these 30 years, it has been one of the main difficult moments in creating consensus. I remember that Equatorial Guinea was admitted in 2014, but there was already a process in the previous analysis phase. There was always an extension, year after year, and it was difficult to reach a consensus within the CPLP countries. In 2014, there was a summit in Timor-Leste and, through the action of Brazil and Angola, there was, in a way, a lot of pressure for Equatorial Guinea to join. But there are two principles, for better and for worse, that justify Equatorial Guinea's presence in the CPLP. What are… The first argument is that, in fact, Equatorial Guinea has Portuguese as its official language in its Constitution, despite us knowing that the Portuguese language, for example, covers four or five percent of society as a whole, and I am already being quite generous. But there is a commitment from the Equatorial Guinea authorities to develop Portuguese as a working language and there is a historical connection to Portuguese culture and Lusophony. Another criterion is the promise that, in the next constitutional review, a commitment will be made to abolish the death penalty. As for Portuguese, it's something that takes generations, it's not done from one year to the next. Not even in the next 10 or 15 years will we have Portuguese perfectly implemented. There is some shyness, a commitment, in a way. As for the death penalty, the fact is that, it seems, some change has been achieved. There has never been a death penalty action again [since accession]. And there is hope that, in the next constitutional review, this fact will be abolished from the Constitution and that it may, effectively, cease to exist. As a member of the CPLP, these changes will be easier and more visible and, in the future, Equatorial Guinea can effectively assume CPLP status taking these premises into account. I don't know if it will happen, I leave here a reluctance, and this is a challenging moment for the CPLP itself. Work needs to be done from within, so that Equatorial Guinea can be at the same level as other countries, especially in these two areas. What is certain is that there remains a certain lack of transparency regarding what is happening in the country. We are aware that Equatorial Guinea has major problems with issues of democratic legitimacy and elections. There are a series of situations that we recognize are not perfectly adequate given the status of CPLP countries. I think there is hope that things can change, an attempt to create space for Portuguese to grow within Equatorial Guinea, and also a commitment to greater openness and participation. What is a fact is that Equatorial Guinea has participated in CPLP meetings, and I have participated in some. In international situations we have to be pragmatic, and we hope that, just because Equatorial Guinea is in the CPLP, this can help Guinea itself to develop some mechanical gestures.

item.title: Timor-Leste / Independence – Mari Alkatiri: Proclamation was anticipated by the Indonesian military presence
item.description: Interview by Isabel Marisa Serafim, from the Lusa agency The leader of the Revolutionary Front of Independent Timor-Leste (Fretilin), Mari Alkatiri, said that the unilateral proclamation of independence was scheduled for December 1, 1975, but was brought forward because Indonesian troops were already in the territory. “It was initially scheduled for December 1st,” said Mari Alkatiri, in an interview with Lusa on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the unilateral declaration of independence, which is marked on Friday, and of the Indonesian occupation, nine days later, on December 7th. In November, Mari Alkatiri went on a “safari” through several African countries, mainly the Portuguese-speaking African Countries (PALOP), which involved participating in the declaration of Angola’s independence on November 11, 1975. "After this 'tour', this African 'safari', I returned to the country.
